and they needed to hear that.They can see now that they have someone who has deep principles, always treats people with the greatest of courtesy but never mistake British politeness for British weakness.Mr Hunt also reiterated it was still possible the UK could exit the EU without a Brexit deal.He said: Because we would never sign up to something that is not consistent with what the British people voted for, then of course it is possible that we don't end up with a deal.We hope that doesn't happen, I've always said that if we don't end up with a deal, Britain would find a way to prosper and flourish.3.50pm update: Hunt throws support behind May's under-fire Chequers planJeremy Hunt has thrown his weight behind Theresa May's Chequers plan, claiming it should continue to remain the basis for negotiations.&nbspThe Foreign Secretary told Sky News the Prime Minister's proposals were still relevant, despite EU leaders outright rejecting them at a summit in Salzburg last week.He said:&nbspI think it's the basis of an agreement and we are very confident that in the end that calm heads will prevail and we can get an agreement, he said.We've never said that we're not prepared to negotiate on inidual elements.Brexit: Jeremy Hunt has warned the EU we will not keep coming back to the negotiating table (Image: )3.28pm update: Hunt warns EU that UK will not keep coming back to negotiating tableJeremy Hunt has warned the EU that Britain will not keep coming back to the negotiating table with more Brexit proposals in an attempt to get a deal over the line.Speaking to Sky News, the Foreign Secretary said Theresa May had already put forward sensible proposals and urged greater engagement from the EU.&nbspWe cannot have a situation in the negotiation between a sovereign power like Britain and one of the biggest countries in the EU and the EU where every time we come up with a proposal, instead of engaging with that proposal they simply say, 'I'm sorry that doesn't work come back with something else'.Negotiations require two parties to engage seriously, that hasn't been happening and Britain is not going to keep coming back with more.We have put on the table some practical proposals, which mean that we can honour the spirit and letter of the referendum and reassure businesses that they can have the frictionless trade that they want.&ldquoThey're sensible proposals, we now need some engagement from the EU.3.10pm update: Government's handling of Brexit an absolute mess, rages boss of No.10's sparkling wine supplierThe boss of the firm that supplies sparkling wine to 10 Downing Street has labelled the Government's handling of Brexit an absolute mess, adding he is planning for the worst and hoping for the best.Fraser Thompson, who heads up England's largest wine producer Chapel Down, told the Press Association that like other businesses, hus doesn't know how Brexit will play out.&nbspChapel Down, which nakes its wine in the UK but imports some packagaing elements from the EU, has previously warned that Britons will starve if the door is closed to foreign fruit pickers after Brexit.&nbspMr Thompson said: All we can do is we can plan for the worst, which is good business governance. It's an absolute mess so we don't know what's going to be the consequence.If you haven't got fruit pickers you're not going to be able to eat strawberries at Wimbledon.Brexit: Theresa May's closest Cabinet ally David Lidington has cast doubt over her future (Image: )3pm update: Brussels to wait until November before kicking off preparations for no-deal Brexit&nbspThe EU will wait until November before significantly ramping up preparations for a possible collapse of Brexit talks, diplomats have told Reuters.&nbspEnvoys of the remaining 27 countries in the bloc after Brexit have discussed stepping up contingency planning in the event of a no-deal scenario and how to manage that process.&nbspA senior EU diplomat told Reuters:&nbspWe will wait for if and when the negotiations with Britain officially fail to kickstart more open work among the 27 on preparing for a no-deal.&ldquoWe've given ourselves until November.The 27 EU leaders have agreed to meet on Movember 17-18 to sign off any Brexit deal the Brussels strikes with Britain.&nbspThe diplomat warned:&nbspThere are areas where we need to act to have something in place on March 30th no matter what.&nbspPaul Withers taking over live reporting from Simon Osborne.2pm update: Liddington questions Theresa May&rsquos futureTheresa May&rsquos closest Cabinet ally has cast doubt on her future as Conservative Party leader.David Lidington said the Prime Minister would decide in due course what she wants to do when he was asked if she should take the Conservatives into the next election.The Cabinet Office Minister's carefully crafted statement suggests Mrs May knows her political days are numbered.He told the Spectator: She said to the party that she will remain leader for as long as they want her to and I think at the moment people are absolutely backing her.She will decide, in due course, what she wants to do. But now, she is focusing on the task in hand.1.20pm update: Hunt insists May is safe in top jobForeign Secretary Jeremy Hunt has insisted Theresa May is safe in her job.Mr Hunt told CNN: She is very secure.Of course, newspapers will write the articles they want to write.But people understand that she's someone of enormous tenacity, resilience.She&rsquos had a very, very difficult few years with the Brexit situation.But she has brought us forward, and she has brought us to the point where a deal is possible, and now we just need to see it through.There is widespread speculation that Mrs May will step down next year once Britain has left the European Union &nbspon March 29, leaving her successor to iron out remaining Brexit details.12.20pm Northern Ireland faces no-deal &ldquoblack-out warningA no-deal Brexit could lead to power cuts across Northern Ireland, government officials have warned.Officials are preparing notices about the impact such of a no-deal scenario on the all-island Single Electricity Market (SEM).They have suggested there are risks of price increases and supply shortages.Most experts have considered the SEM to be a relatively unproblematic part of Brexit because it is a UK-Ireland bilateral arrangement, rather than an EU arrangement.But it is underpinned by the UK and Ireland's membership of the Internal Energy Market (IEM), participation of which requires alignment with EU rules including industrial emissions regulations and restrictions on state aid.Jeremy Corbyn is meeting Michel Barnier and Martin Selmayr (Image: REUTERS)11.49am update: &ldquoKeep calm and keep negotiatingEuropean Commission officials insist they are working hard for a Brexit deal and dismissed as horror stories reports they were stepping up contingency planning in case negotiations with Britain collapse.Chief spokesman Margaritis Schinas said the focus in Brussels was still on getting an agreement with the UK.He said acknowledged the commission was at the same time not abandoning its duties when it came to preparing for any possible outcomes, including a no-deal Brexit.But he added: &ldquoKeep calm and keep negotiating.11.21am update: MEP demands realistic proposals on Irish border issuePolish MEP Danuta Hubner has demanded the UK produce &ldquorealistic proposals on the Irish border and post-Brexit partnership after Theresa May was humiliated by her European counterparts in Salzburg.Ms Hubner, a member of the European Parliament&rsquos Brexit steering group, warned time is running out for both Westminster and Brussels to agree a &ldquolegally-viable Irish backstop, which the EU&rsquos most senior officials have said must be agreed by October.She described the Irish border as the &ldquomost worrying of the outstanding issues still to be agreed by Michel Barnier and Dominic Raab, writing in a piece for the Scottish Centre on European Relations.10.27am update: Amber Rudd backs second referendum in event of no-deal BrexitFormer home secretary&nbspAmber Rudd said she would absolutely support a second referendum&nbsp&nbspon the UK's membership of the EU over no-deal.She said: I don't think no deal will happen.I think that if we can't get a negotiated deal, that the Prime Minister brings back through Parliament, then I think that we're in completely uncharted territory.I think that one of the outcomes you might get is a Norway style EEA deal, and I know that various colleagues are looking at that.9.26am update: Corbyn issues statement ahead of Brussels talksJeremy Corbyn has released a statement ahead of his Brussels meetings with Michel Barnier and controversial European Commission secretary-general Martin Selmayr.The Labour leader said: &ldquoWith just weeks of negotiating time left, it&rsquos clear that UK-EU Brexit talks are in a perilous state.&ldquoTime is running out and companies are losing patience with the absence of any clarity from the government.&ldquoCrashing out of Europe with no deal risks being a national disaster.&ldquoThat is why I&rsquom meeting EU officials today, and I will be urging them to do all they can to avoid a no-deal outcome, which would be so damaging to jobs and living standards in both the UK and EU countries.Michel Barnier and Dominic Raab  (Image: )8.37am update: Budget brought forward to avoid Brexit summit clashChancellor Philip Hammond has brought forward the date of his autumn budget statement to avoid a clash with crunch Brexit talks.Mr Hammond&nbspwill now deliver the budget on Monday October 29, earlier than usual, as the Government prepares for a crucial Brexit summit in November.Chancellors normally deliver their autumn statements on the budget in November but EU leaders are due to hold a special summit on November 17 and 18 to thrash out the terms of Britain&rsquos exit from the bloc if sufficient progress in negotiations has been made by then.The mid-November summit was called by European Council President Donald Tusk during last week&rsquos tense gathering in Salzburg.8am update: Barnier furious at Brexit transport lettersMichel Barnier has ticked off Dominic Raab after finding the Government had written to the 27 other member states asking for side negotiations on transport in the event of a no-deal Brexit.The Brexit Secretary was confronted by Mr Barnier during their most recent meeting in Brussels over correspondence sent in recent days to EU capitals by the Department for Transport.The letters asked the member states to prepare to engage with the British government in side deals on aviation and haulage, to allow key trade flows to continue in the event of the UK and the EU failing to come to an agreement on leaving the union by 29 March 2019.A furious Mr Barnier is said to have told Mr Raab: &ldquoIf there is no deal, there is no trust.Emmanuel Macron backs a second referendum (Image: BLOOMBERG)7.30am update: Corbyn heads to Brussels for Brexit talks with BarnierLabour leader Jeremy Corbyn will hold private talks with EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier today after vowing to vote against Theresa May&rsquos Chequers proposals.Party officials are keen to portray Mr Corbyn as a potential Prime Minister if failure to reach a Brexit deal leads to a snap election.An insider said: &ldquoJeremy will lay out Labour&rsquos plans and what he would do in government to break the Brexit impasse.Mr Corbyn will meet Mr Barnier after attending a ceremony at a square in Brussels that will be named after the late Labour MP Jo Cox who was murdered by a far-right extremist in June 2016.7am update: Macron backs second referendumEmmanuel Macron is backing a second EU referendum and said he would be happy to welcome Britain back into the fold if the Brexit decision was reversed at the polls.The French President repeated his claims that Leave campaigners &ldquolied to voters in the run-up to the June 2016 poll when he was interviewed at the One Planet Summit on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly in New York.He said: &ldquoBrexit costs a lot. It&rsquos much more complicated than they initially thought.Mr Macron said he would support another referendum but insisted it was not up to him to decide if Britain held another Brexit vote.When asked if he would welcome Britain back to the EU he replied: &ldquoFor sure. This is about history, not about domestic interests.

story: Asked if she should take the Conservatives into the next election, David Lidington said the Prime Minister would decide in due course what she wants to do.The Cabinet Office Minister's carefully crafted statement suggests Mrs May knows her political days are numbered.It could also be seen as a bid to head off any leadership coup to topple her early, by reassuring rivals she does not expect to make good on previous hints that she will still be in charge at the next election.Mr Lidington spoke to The Spectator magazine ahead of the annual Conservative party conference which opens on Sunday in Birmingham.                Theresa May blasts Archbishop as he attacks Tory poverty recordMrs May's leadership is expected to come under intense pressure from hostile activists and MPs unhappy with her leadership and her handling of Brexit in particular.Mr Lidington, who is seen as Mrs May's deputy in all but name, was asked if he wanted her to lead the party into the next election.He responded: She said to the party that she will remain leader for as long as they want her to and I think at the moment people are absolutely backing her.Pressed again, he said: She will decide, in due course, what she wants to do.David Lidington said the Prime Minister would  (Image: )But now, she is focusing on the task in hand.Earlier, Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt told American television that resilient Mrs May was safe in her job.From New York where he attending the United Nations general assembly summit, he told CNN when asked if the PM had seen off a leadership challenge: She is very secure.Of course, newspapers will write the articles they want to write.                Remoaner calls on May to &lsquoMAKE WAY&rsquo for Labour if negotiations fail                Jeremy Corbyn goes against Labour with partial SUPPORT May&rsquos BrexitBut people understand that she's someone of enormous tenacity, resilience.She&rsquos had a very, very difficult few years with the Brexit situation.But she has brought us forward, and she has brought us to the point where a deal is possible, and now we just need to see it through.Mr Hunt is himself seen as a potential leadership hopeful when a contest takes place.There is widespread speculation that Mrs May will step down next year once Britain has left the European Union on March 29, leaving her successor to iron out remaining Brexit details.

story: He also raised concerns that Government policies designed to curb corporate excess risked surrendering political ground to the Left.We can&rsquot out-Corbyn Corbyn, and if we try, we risk offering a pale imitation that leaves people yearning for the real thing.Mr Gyimah delivered his remarks in an article in Westminster's The House magazine ahead of the party's autumn gathering in Birmingham at the weekend.Similar criticisms about the direction of the party under the Prime Minister's leadership are expected to be raised by a series of senior figures at the conference.                END OF MAY: PM's closest ally drops HUGE HINT she could quit                 Brexit news: Corbyn warns Barnier Labour are ready to VOTE DOWN dealWhen I look at how we on the centre-right have reacted to the perceived failing of capitalism, I can&rsquot help thinking we have lost our way, wrote Mr Gyimah, whose brief is split between Whitehall's Business and Education departments.Disconcerted by a shift in the zeitgeist against business, and by the cumulative surprises of the financial crisis, the EU referendum and the 2017 general election, we appear to have become confused about how to handle business.Sometimes we appear to accept criticisms of capitalism at face value and feel the need to respond accordingly &ndash a futile task.Mr Gyimah urged senior Tories to re-engage with business leaders rather than relentlessly attacking them.Theresa May has been accused of losing her way  (Image: EXPRESS)British Minister of State for Higher Education Sam Gyimah (C)  (Image: )When we Conservatives veer between talking business down, ignoring voters&rsquo concerns, and telling businesses to shut up &ndash or worse &ndash it is clear sign we have lost our way.When it comes to our relationship with business, we must unscramble our compass if we are to stand any chance of defeating the hard Left.Mr Gyimah argued the Tories were most electoral successful when their instincts to reinvigorate capitalism matched with the challenge of the time.We need to realise that if we are not the party of business then we are nothing. So we need to find our way, and quickly.And that should start with remembering what has made us successful in the past.                Brexit: Labour minister says party will 'COMPROMISE' on Brexit deal                 Corbyn CONCEDES Labour NOT negotiating after meeting with BarnierOur remarkable electoral record over the last century has been in no small part down to our relationship with business.As times changed our electoral success was based on our ability to reinvigorate capitalism &ndash not fix it &ndash in order to match the challenge of the time, he wrote.He highlighted how the Tory prime minister Margaret Thatcher grasped faster than anyone the dynamics of the entrepreneurial, post-industrial society that Britain was becoming.We are at our best when we are pro-enterprise and pro-endeavour, and when we do this in a way that is clear that our motive is to make the world a better place and improve the lot of ordinary citizens.But if all voters hear from us is an echo of the left&rsquos concerns, and singing from Labour&rsquos hymn sheet, without an enthusiastic and full-throated endorsement of open markets, and without trumpeting our record, we will have only ourselves to blame when they turn away from capitalism, he wrote.Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn at the Labour Party Conference  (Image: REUTERS)Former Tory minister Robert Halfon also raised concerns about the party's direction last night.On Twitter, he warned that some of the ideas raised by Labour at its conference in Liverpool may resonate with millions of workers.Mr Halfon said: Conservatives need a thoughtful response to this at conference with a true vision and passion for a workers - predictable responses just won't cut it with public.And senior Tory MP George Freeman, a former chief policy adviser in Number 10, wrote in an article in The House magazine: Amongst a new generation of voters under 45, both capitalism and our model of liberal democracy are suffering a deep crisis of unpopularity.A new generation of aspirational professional voters under 45 are rejecting the old model.Unless the Conservative Party reconnects with them, we risk becoming a rump party of nostalgic nationalists.

title: Corbyn slammed EU talks
story: Jeremy Corbyn arrived in Belgium to discuss Brexit with Michel Barnier (Image: REUTERS )He used the meeting to tell the diplomat of his intention to reject any deal that fails six tests set by his party.&nbspBut Brexit campaigners attacked his intervention as a fresh attempt to undermine the country&rsquos negotiating position in his drive to bring down Theresa May&rsquos Government.&nbspFormer Ukip leader Nigel Farage, a leading figure in the Leave Means Leave campaign, said the meeting &ldquowas clearly an attempt to undermine negotiations after he promised to vote down May&rsquos deal, adding: &ldquoHe is obviously believed by the European Commission to be a useful idiot. But I&rsquom sure workingclass people who voted Leave will feel betrayed and angry at his ill thought-out strategy to betray British interests.&nbspTory MP Ben Bradley added: &ldquoWe&rsquove see this week that Corbyn and Labour want us to continue to take EU rules and pay in through a customs union, or even hold a new vote if they can get away with it.&nbsp                Jeremy Corbyn goes against Labour with partial SUPPORT May&rsquos Brexit                'We've lost our way' May warned Tories risk handing power to Corbyn&ldquoCorbyn&rsquos involvement in these discussions behind closed doors can be of no benefit to Britain and only serves to further complicate an already difficult negotiation.&ldquoIf he can&rsquot get on board and back the UK in these talks, he should stay out of it.A Government source described Mr Corbyn&rsquos visit to Brussels as &ldquounhelpful.&nbspThe Labour leader said they had an &ldquointeresting, useful discussion but admitted the EU diplomat had offered &ldquono opinion on the opposition&rsquos Brexit plans.&nbspEarlier, Mr Corbyn spoke at a ceremony to name a Brussels square after murdered Labour MP Jo Cox, who had lived in the city for six years before arriving at the Commons.&nbsp

story: BBC QUESTION Time returns tonight with David Dimbleby (Image: Getty)The two MPs will sit on the panel and will be going head to head in a heated debate.Polly Mackenzie, former adviser to Nick Clegg, political commentator Rod Liddle, and Ayesha Hazarika, columnist for the Evening Standard, make the rest of the line-up.Topics which are likely to be discussed on the BBC&rsquos topical debate programme this week include Labour&rsquos Party Conference in Liverpool, Theresa May&rsquos humiliation in Salzburg, the United Nations General Assembly in New York and the revelation one of Skripal suspect &ldquowas made hero of Russia with a medal by President Putin.Live updates from the show can be found below. title: Brexit news Jeremy Corbyn Brussels Labour Party Michel Barnier meeting Theresa May
story: The hard-left Labour leader told Mr Barnier his party were prepared to vote down the Prime Minister&rsquos Brexit agreement if the deal does not meet their strict &ldquosix tests.Mr Corbyn and his shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer were hosted by bloc&rsquos controversial top civil servant Martin Selmayr before their high level talks with Mr Barnier.Speaking to reporters outside, Mr Corbyn explained the &ldquosix tests on which Labour will use to hold the British Government to account with in the future.&ldquoEssentially, the protection of jobs and the trade arrangements with the European Union and, of course, the issue surrounding the border in Ireland, he explained.Mr Corbyn added: What we did was set out our views, which we&rsquove set out very carefully and I must say he was very well aware of what both of us have said at our party conference and he then set out in broad terms what the progress is and what the timetable is and the importance of reaching an agreement.We discussed with him our six tests which are about ensuring that the manufacturing industry and supply chain is intact on both sides of the Channel and that EU nationals&rsquo position in Britain is secure and that there is no hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.The Labour Party leader revealed Mr Barnier was keen to hear about his party's Brexit plans, however, offered no opinion to his Brussels guests.                Brexit: Labour minister says party will 'COMPROMISE' on Brexit deal Mr Corbyn and Sir Keir's meeting is the sixth occasion they discussed Brexit with Mr Barnier.The shady meeting with Mr Selmayr, who oversees the EU&rsquos no-deal preparation, offers potential hints to how the bloc foresees Brexit&rsquos future, despite repeat claims it is working towards a deal.It is acknowledged Mr Selmayr requested the meeting in order to gain an understanding of Labour&rsquos plans directly from Mr Corbyn.At the Labour conference in Liverpool, the party&rsquos leader said opposition MPs &ldquowill vote against any reduction in right, standards or protections and oppose a deregulatory race-to-the-bottom.Mr Corbyn hopes by sinking the Prime Minister's Brexit deal he will be able to trigger a general election and launch himself into Downing Street.Despite being prepared to leave the country on the brink of a no-deal orce, Mr Corbyn spent two hours inside the Berlaymont building asking EU officials to do their best to strike a deal in order to avert a &ldquonational disaster in Britain.Brexit news: Jeremy Corbyn warns Michel Barnier of Labour's plan to vote down Government's deal (Image: )Prior to the showdown, the Labour leader said: &ldquoWith just weeks of negotiating time left, it&rsquos clear that UK-EU Brexit talks are in a perilous state. Time is running out and companies are losing patience with the absence of any clarity from the government.&ldquoCrashing out of Europe with no deal risks being a national disaster. That is why I&rsquom meeting EU officials today, and I will be urging them to do all they can to avoid a &lsquono-deal&rsquo outcome, which would be so damaging to jobs and living standards in both the UK and EU countries.He is demanding that Mrs May&rsquos post-Brexit deal offers a customs union with the EU, prevents a hard border in Ireland, protects jobs, people&rsquos rights at work and environmental and consumer standards.The cost of his support mirrors Labour&rsquos &ldquosix tests but is lesser than previous calls for a deal that achieves &ldquothe exact same benefits of both single market and customs union membership.Mr Corbyn and Sir Keir visited the European Commission while in Brussels to as part of the ceremony to rename a square in honour of the late Jo Cox, a Labour MP murdered in 2016.After paying their sombre tribute to their former colleague, the pair stopped off for a strategy meeting in a local brasserie, where Mr Corbyn feasted on a Greek salad.In an embarrassing mishap en route to the EU&rsquos headquarters, which could offer insight into Mr Corbyn&rsquos fiscal understanding, Labour aides were forced to scramble around for euros to pay their taxi driver.His communications chief Seumas Milne told waiting reporters: &ldquoThere&rsquos no end to the problems with this.An unimpressed Nigel Farage accused Mr Corbyn of being used as a useful idiot by the European Commission in their bid to secure a Brexit deal they are satisfied with.He told Express: Corbyn arranging to &nbspmeet Selmayr and Barnier was clearly an attempt to undermine negotiations after he promised to vote down May&rsquos deal.He is obviously believed by the European Commission to be a useful idiot.But I'm sure that working class people who voted leave will feel betrayed and angry at his ill- thought out stategy to betray British interests.

story: With less than two months to go until the crucial midterm elections on November 6, the former Deputy Chairman of the Conservative Party conducted a 6,000-sample poll of US voters to provide a snapshot of the national mood as the respective parties&rsquo campaigns build speed.It revealed that nearly half (48 percent) of Democratic voters think the party&rsquos &ldquopolicies and ideas are basically right, but they just need too improve the way they communicate them.Nearly a third (32 percent) think the Democrats need to rethink their policies and ideas to win over US people who have not voted for them in the past, while eight percent think they are already on course to win elections in the next few years and don&rsquot need to change much at all.The poll showed the US public are largely ided in terms of the job the Democrats are doing in opposing Donald Trump&rsquos policies.                US midterms: Trump voters give president 14-POINT boost - poll                Midterm elections in US: When are the 2018 midterm elections? It also revealed that only around one in 10 Democrats expect the US President to be re-elected.Lord Ashcroft said if the Democrats&rsquo direction is set by their most committed activists, &ldquowe know from previous research those activists are far removed in terms of values and outlook from the kind of voters who deserted the party in the Midwest two years ago.He added it would be &ldquobrave of the Democrats to continue to turn their back on those voters and not try to win them back.But Lord Ashcroft, who resigned as deputy chairman of the Conservative Party in in September 2010 after nearly five years in the role, warned the Democratic path is starting to mirror that of the Labour Party in the UK nearly a decade ago.In 1997, Labour defeated the Conservatives with a 179 seat majority that saw Tony Blair become Prime Minister for eight years, before stepping down and being replaced by Gordon Brown in 2005.Lord Ashcroft's poll shows one in 10 Democrats expect Donald Trump to be re-elected (Image: )Nearly half of Democratic voters think the party's  (Image: LORD ASHCROFT POLLS)But after 13 years in power, Labour were defeated by the Conservatives in the 2010 general election, when the Tories formed a coalition Government with the Liberal Democrats.Labour has remained out of power since and Lord Ashcroft claimed they leant more to the left when Ed Miliband took over as the party&rsquos leader eight years ago.According to a national poll by YouGov from September 24-25, the Conservatives polled 42 percent of the vote compared to Labour&rsquos 36 percent - it&rsquos biggest lead so far this year.Lord Ashcroft warned the Democrats could find themselves cast into political shadows like Labour if they continue to lean to the left.He said: &ldquoAfter the Labour landslide of 1997, it took the Conservatives eight years to take the hint and start making the changes they needed.                Donald Trump US midterm BOOST as MAJORITY believe progress being made                Midterm elections US: Donald Trump &lsquoin HALL OF FAME of US presidents&rsquoNearly two thirds of voters think the Democrats represent &ldquothe values of people like me (Image: LORD ASHCROFT POLLS)&ldquoWhen they managed to unseat Gordon Brown in 2010, Labour supporters believed &ndash just like today&rsquos Democrats &ndash that they had lost because voters didn&rsquot understand the issues, the media hadn&rsquot done its job properly, and that their own policies had been right but not sufficiently well communicated.&ldquoThey went on to choose as their leader Ed Miliband, the candidate who made them feel best about being in the Labour Party, after which they lost again, and promptly went even further into their comfort zone on the left &ndash perhaps the main reason why the Tories still have the edge in the polls despite the political turmoil.&ldquoIt remains to be seen whether the Democrats will do &ldquothe full Jeremy Corbyn or whether they have the discipline to try to win back the voters they once took for granted.&ldquoBut that decision, as much as anything else, will determine what happens in two years&rsquo time.

title: jane moore katie price rehab romance
story: The second time was in January 2016, behind the scenes of Loose Women.In the intervening years, I had made several waspish remarks about her on this very page  so fully expected a frosty exchange.But she was disarmingly self-deprecating, funny and, to my utter surprise, very much a woman’s woman.“I know you think I’m a nightmare,” she said matter-of-factly. “And you’re probably right. But I think we’re going to get on.”She was right. We did. The other panellists liked her too.Predominantly mothers, we treated her as one might a naughty niece you were particularly fond of, rolling our eyes and smiling affectionately as she regaled us with the latest relationship drama in her le.But despite her no-nonsense, often humorous delivery, there was always a faint “here we go again” sadness behind her eyes and, as I saw it, a low self-esteem that might explain the constant cosmetic alterations and propensity to criticise herself before anyone else could.After reading the recent headlines of wild nights out and rap songs about cocaine, it’s easy to think that Katie is a party girl who has largely abandoned her children as an inconvenience to the carefree lestyle she longs to have.And, judging by yesterday’s letters page, plenty of you do.Before getting to know her, I might have shared that view. But now I see her admittedly destructive behaviour as a cry for help and I’m relieved that, finally, she’s in to rehab to get it.Once, in a rare flash of what I feel is the real Katie, she told me that her Holy Grail was to find a decent, dependable man who could pay the bills while she stayed home and ran a large, chaotic farmhouse full of children and animals.Her favourite night of the week was Friday, when she would wipe off her “work face”, slip in to her old trackie bottoms and call in a takeaway for her, her now estranged third husband Kieran and the kids.Anyone who has seen her interacting with Harvey, her severely disabled eldest son, will know that she’s a fundamentally devoted mother doing her best  in often trying circumstances.Remember her in the I’m A Celebrity jungle? Free of make-up, her hair in braids, tackling each challenge with an admirably no-nonsense bravado? To my mind, that’s the real Katie — the rest is just noise.But without doubt, she has a self-destructive streak when she feels let down.So, after catching Kieran having an affair with her “best friend”, forgiving him, then catching him again with someone else, it was inevitable that a fall was coming. Her mum Amy said at the weekend: “Kate has been her own worst enemy and behaved like an idiot at times but she has been tearing herself apart for years.“All the men in her le have used Katie, and never, ever leave her alone . . . Kieran almost destroyed Kate with his behaviour, Alex  has been as bad, and Pete  likes to portray himself as perfect . . . they all know that  they wind her up, she will react.“Kate is stupid for reacting, but these men need to look at how they are behaving and take some responsibility.”Wise words. And Katie needs to heed them as much as her former husbands.She’s always been disarmingly frank about the incidents in her le that would have sent many of us over the edge — not least being sexually abused when she was just six years old. But now it’s time for her to stop shrugging them off as “just one of those things” and take a long, hard look at how they’ve shaped her often destructive behaviour patterns as an adult.I hope she sticks with the therapy and, ultimately, finds contentment.HOT on the stilettos of Stormy Daniels’ lurid description of Donald Trump’s manhood, singer Cher has been regaling us with tales of her former lovers.Tom Cruise is in her “top five” but legendary lothario Warren Beatty was, apparently, a disappointment.Cher, 72, explains: “Not that he wasn’t technically good, but I didn’t feel anything.”We remain blissfully unaware of whether she means emotionally or physically.EAGLE-EYED travellers boarding a flight operated by Hong Kong airline Cathay Pacic noticed this glaring spelling error on the side of the plane.Though it grieves me greatly, spelling errors or “typos” are now commonplace in everyday exchanges via text, tweet or email, but it never ceases to amaze me when they’re writ large on something as expensive as a sign, billboard or, er, Boeing 747.Does no one check these things before literally advertising their ignorance? Seems not.And so, we are entertained by such gems as Shoplters Will Be Prostituted, Chris Is Risen, All Busniesses Open As Usual, Pay and Display Apples In This Area, Costumers Only, Parrallel Parking, No Trough Road and Pedestrain Crossing, to name but a few.And don’t even get me started on missing or misplaced apostraffy’s…WHEN cookery presenter Nadiya Hussain was picked to bake the Queen’s birthday cake in 2016, she recalls feeling that it was an opportunity to act against Islamophobia.“Everybody thinks it, ‘Oh God, who let the Muslim woman near the Queen with a kne?’” she says now. “Let’s address that elephant in the room, because they did.”Nope. Actually, I remember thinking, “Oh, it’s that lovely woman who won Bake Off and made Mary Berry cry tears of joy”.Sorry to disappoint, Nadiya.Quite right too.Particularly as the majority of them are now more recognisable than the “celebrities” they’re dancing with.HOLLYWOOD director Sam Mendes says his now defunct marriage to Kate Winslet struggled because he “was not very comfortable being married to a celebrity . . . it made me feel self-conscious”.Couldn’t he have worked that out before they trotted down the aisle?VIDEO game designers are working on giving avatars real-le emotions to make the experience more authentic.Will they include a frustrated parent yelling: “Get off that bloody thing before you turn in to someone with the physical and people skills of an atrophied three-toed sloth?No, thought not.ACTRESS Helena Bonham Carter says she used a psychic to contact Princess Margaret so she could perfect her role as the Queen’s sister in the forthcoming third series of The Crown.She claims Margaret told her she’s “doing a great job”.Hmmm. From what little one knows of the feisty royal, “fack orf” seems more likely.FRANK SPRINGETT is 91, his we Mary is 86 and they have been married for 67 years.Frank is deaf and suffers from arthritis, Mary has severe Alzheimer’s, and both are being looked after in the same Warwickshire-based care home using funds from the sale of their house.However, the money is now running low and while social services will continue to partially pay for Mary’s care, it says former factory worker Frank has to look after himself.Meaning that 70 years after they met, they face being separated for the first time.“We fear  they are torn apart, the strain will kill them,” says their daughter Joanne, 57.With seemingly endless funds being readily shelled out to help accommodate those  who seek asylum in Britain, how sad that someone who has paid in to the system all their le gets so let down when they need it most.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brussels eu press regulation sun
story: Justice commissioner Vera Jourova was riled by our front page labelling EU leaders “dirty rats” over their tactics.She accused the UK media of spreading “disinformation” and suggested “smart regulation”.Speaking in Austria, Ms Jourova said: “Media can build the culture of dialogue or sow isions, spread disinformation and encourage exclusion.“The Brexit debate is the best example of that. Do you remember the front page of a popular British daily calling the judges the ‘enemy of the people’?Or just last week, the EU leaders were called ‘dirty rats’ on another front page.Almost daily we could find examples of stories that are spiced up to point out the enemy, to paint the picture black and white.I would advocate for a European approach to media based on quality and smart regulation,  needed.But Tory MEP Amjad Bashir said: “Commissioners should not be trying to shackle the Press.“We politicians do not always like what journalists write, but they have to be free to report the news as they see it.The vibrancy and iety of our newspapers is one of the things that makes Britain great.People have to learn to take the rough with the smooth.Otherwise we are on a slippery slope to state control and oppression.Mr Bashir’s colleague Ashley Fox added: “A free and unfettered media is vital.” EU officials insisted there was no new legislative action in the pipeline in terms of media regulation and that Ms Jourova had been talking about broadcasters.A Commission spokeswoman said she was merely trying to “trigger a discussion”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: And some of them chanting the slogan “from the river to the sea” favoured by Hamas and the PLO, who demand the liquidation of Israel.Lovely people.That will have put to rest any worries the British Jewish community might have, no? title: homework works parents help
story: He thinks he is stupid and that little Amy is clever because she knows all the answers.What he doesn’t realise is that Amy does her homework with her family every night.American comedian Rob Delaney ignited a lively debate when he tweeted: “Why do they give seven-year-olds so much homework in the UK and how do I stop this?I want my kid frolicking and drawing and playing football.”Fellow celebrities Gary Lineker and Jason Manford agreed.Piers Morgan disagreed, calling the arguments “lazy parenting”.I have to disagree too with Mr Delaney and his supporters.Homework is essential for a child’s education because revisiting the day’s learning is what helps to make it stick.So Catastrophe star Rob and Gary Lineker are wrong in attacking compulsory home-work in primary schools.Sure, you’ll get the odd exceptionally bright pupil who will excel just through what she learns at school, despite not having that support at home.But this is very rare.Teaching is not just the teacher’s job.It takes a village to raise a child.Children learn all the time and the environment surrounding them determines how much they learn.Genes play a part in how clever a child is, but how hard they work also matters.Work hard and you’ll learn lots.Work less and you’ll learn less.Don’t make the mistake of thinking homework is for a child to do on their own.When parents use homework to bond and learn together with their child, the child understands that Mum and Dad value learning.And because a child wants to please their parents, the child’s interest in their home-work will grow, year on year.These children can see the benefit of homework and will enjoy doing it because it makes them feel better about themselves.Everyone loves to feel successful.Ten years ago, author Malcolm Gladwell introduced the idea that it takes 10,000 hours of practice to become an expert in something.We get better at what we practise, whether it’s football or maths.Our brains have a working memory and a long-term memory.If your times tables are stored in your long-term memory, you will quickly be able to calculate what it will cost to buy 12 apples instead of two.If that knowledge isn’t there, you’ll have to resort to counting on your fingers.The more knowledge stored in long-term memory, the better equipped you’ll be to think imaginatively and solve complex problems.Homework revisits what you learn at school to cement it into your long-term memory.I do agree that some home-work is pointless.Silly craft projects that involve gluing things together, which the parent will inevitably end up doing, hold no value for me.I also understand why some parents don’t like homework — they feel that it’s a battle.Parenting is hard.I get that.But we need to stop thinking of homework as a chore that the child is sent off to do, cutting into the parent’s precious time with them.It shouldn’t be the case on Sunday night that Mum says: “Oh God, it’s homework time — let’s get it over with.”Instead, learning should be part of daily le, and an enriching time for both the parent and the child.Reading with your child for 20 minutes should not be a chore.Asking them to count peas on their plate should not be hard work.While you’re out in the street, talk to them about the world around them.This is the sort of homework that is often set for very young children and it can be done without making it feel like a formal lesson.It doesn’t need to be half an hour sitting at a desk.It can just be ten minutes of enjoyable time together.Homework can be written down but can also be spoken or done online, leaving little marking for the teacher.Secondary-school homework can help you learn with your child.You can learn some French again or be reminded of the beauty of Shakespeare!How wonderful is that?By scaffolding the support at home, you can gradually wean them off it, just like taking off bike stabilisers.Eventually, they learn to work independently, so that when they get to GCSEs, they will be in the habit of doing their homework each night.If you don’t get them into the homework habit from an early age, you risk having a battle with a stroppy teen as they approach their exams.And no parent wants that.Those who are against homework will argue that their children have no time for other hobbies.This is nonsense.Children generally finish school at 3.15pm, and younger ones tend to go to bed at about 8pm.That’s nearly five hours of free time.Are they really spending it playing hockey or going to Brownies?I doubt it.Half an hour of homework in five hours of spare time is a drop in the ocean, leaving lots of time for other things.The real worry for parents should be how much time children are spending on social media — something that is so very dangerous and takes up hours of their time, unlike homework.Katharine Birbalsingh is head of Michaela Community School, North London, and has been dubbed the country’s “strictest head teacher”.She introduced an ultra-disciplined approach to learning called Tiger Teaching.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gay penguins kidnap chick from straight parents at denmark zoo
story: Apparently the drama unfolded in a zoo in Denmark when the chick’s mum and dad were having their daily paddle.Animal keeper Sandie Hedegård Munck told Danish broadcaster DR the male penguin couple at Odense Zoo have been desperate to become parents.So, she claims when they saw the chick being “neglected” by its parents, they decided to intervene and snatch it in hope of adopting it.Sandie said: I could see that something was completely wrong. The parents disappeared and the kid was simply kidnapped. It was a pair of gay males who had snatched it and was stood with it.”Sandie said she believed the mum had gone for her daily bath and when she did not  in time for the dad appeared to have forgotten all about his parental responsibilities and left the baby alone.She added: “When they saw him alone they probably thought ‘that’s too bad, we’ll snatch it.It was thought the mum and dad would  and claim their chick back, but that did not immediately happen.  Eventually they did come looking for it and it was decided to give them custody of the bird.Seemingly scandalised by the sight, the Edwardian scientist described the behaviour as depraved. More recently the behaviour has been observed in a number of zoos. In 2014 Jumbs and Hurricane, two Humboldt penguins at Wingham Wildle Park in Kent became inseparable and became celebrities in their own right.They later successfully hatched and reared an egg given to them as surrogate parents after the mum abandoned it halfway through incubation.At first the flightless, two-toned fellas got in a flap about giving up their adopted child without a fight, but Sandie said with a heavy heart they eventually let go.But while this may pull at heartstrings, there is a happy ending to the story because the zookeepers, after seeing how they cared for the baby, have decided to give them an egg from a new mum who was unable to look after her offspring because of illness.

title: david beckham mr loophole road safety campaigners speeding
story: The ex-England captain David Beckham wont face prosecution after his lawyer, dubbed Mr Loophole, got him off on a technicality.The former Manchester United star had been accused of driving a borrowed £200,000 Bentley at 59mph in a 40mph zone on the A40 in Paddington on the afternoon of January 23.But celebrity lawyer Nick Freeman managed to successfully fight the allegation, pointing out the notice of intended prosecution was defective because it arrived on February 7 - one day later than the deadline set by law.Last night infuriated speeding groups accused the star of “shirking responsibility”.Not least because the former United winger posted an Instagram snap on the same day complaining about traffic in London.Joshua Harris of safety group Brake slammed him for using “a technicality” to escape.He said: “It’s hugely disappointing to see a role model like David Beckham shirking his responsibility and getting off a speeding prosecution on a technicality.“At the speed he was reported to be travelling, his stopping distance would be double that of someone driving within the limit — he should count himself very lucky that no incident occurred.”Claire Armstrong of Safe Speed Campaign said: “This says  you have enough money you can lead a dferent le to everyone else. It also appears to show speeding is not seen as dangerous by courts.”Angry parents took to Facebook to slam dad-of-four Beckham as a “bad role model” for their kids.One wrote: “If he’d hit a child at that speed it would have died. We have limits for a reason.”Beckham, of Holland Park in West London, did not attend the trial at Wimbledon Magistrates Court. He was instead spotted at Kings Cross St Pancras international station, home to the Eurostar.Its thought the 43-year-old dad was travelling to Paris for the citys fashion week. His we Victoria is already in the French capital.On his way to the station Beckham snapped a selfie captioned: Angry...London traffic.Sat in the back of a Range Rover, Beckham was wearing a beanie hat and sunglasses and posing with his hand behind his head.Meanwhile in court, Mr Freeman today argued that it would be unsafe to allow the proceedings to continue because of what he claimed was a lack of admissible prosecution evidence." data-credit="" data-sizes="auto" data-img="https:www.thesun/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/beck1.jpg?strip=all&ampw=767" height="273" width="767"/7 " data-credit="" data-sizes="auto" data-img="https:www.thesun/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/beck2.jpg?strip=all&ampw=785" height="328" width="785"/7 " data-credit="" data-sizes="auto" data-img="https:www.thesun/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/beck3.jpg?strip=all&ampw=770" height="326" width="770"/7And after five and a half hours, District Judge Barbara Barnes found the notice of intended prosecution was one day outside the legal limit.It came after she warned Mr Freeman that a tribunal could reasonably convict Beckham on the evidence and ruled there was a case to answer.The high-profile celebrity lawyer has previously represented the likes of ex-cricketer Andrew Flintoff, former Manchester United manager Sir Alex Ferguson and ex-Liverpool goalkeeper Pepe Reina.Almost 20 years ago, Mr Freeman helped Beckham win an earlier appeal against an eight-month driving ban.The trial heard from four witnesses regarding the sending of a notice of intended prosecution, which arrived a day outside the statutory 14-day window.In his submission Mr Freeman told the court: If the Crown cant prove that the letter was sent by first class post then the concept that it arrives in two working days goes out of the window.It would be unsafe to allow these proceedings to go any further.He added: David Beckham is the defendant but in relation to today - whats on trial is the Bentley postal system.He said that while Beckham accepted his driving, the issue was over the letter arriving late. A not guilty plea was entered on August 17.The court was also told Beckham had been wrongly sent a separate fixed penalty notice two months after a Ford vehicle was driven through a red traffic light.The defence barrister said: It shows there are mistakes in the system and this is one of the key players in that system. He had no involvement whatsoever in this offence.Beckham made his name as a midfielder at Manchester United in the 1990s before going on to play for Real Madrid, LA Galaxy, AC Milan and Paris Saint-Germain.He also earned 115 caps for the national side.District Judge Barbara Barnes rejected the claim that notice was served on time, and cleared Beckham of the driving offence on the legal technicality.She said: What I find is that it did not arrive in the post-room at Bentley Motors Limited until February 7 and that therefore by one day was just outside of the required legal limit.As a result of my finding then the defendant in this case cant be convicted.Beckham retired from playing in 2013.Beckham and his we, former Spice Girl Victoria have built up a multi-million pound empire through Victorias fashion house, clothing lines with retailers and product endorsements.WE’LL be blunt, Becks.It is repugnant to see a celebrity smugly dodge justice solely thanks to being rich enough for a fancy lawyer skilled at exploiting loopholes.Especially when that star freely admits doing 59mph in a 40 zone.Millions of ordinary people grimly suck up fines they can ill afford for far lesser speeding offences.Even  their prosecution letter arrives a day late.Beckham may be within the letter of the law, but not its spirit.That’s a bad look for a man desperate for public adulation and establishment approval

title: emmanuel macron reverse brexit second referendum
story: The French president even suggested a re-run of the referendum might be necessary because voters didnt grasp how complex the issue was when they backed Brexit two years ago.Mr Macron insisted he didnt want to meddle in British politics - despite saying hed love to have the UK back in the EU.Asked  European leaders would welcome Britain back after a second referendum, he told Bloomberg: For sure.He denied that he secretly wants the UK to leave so Paris can grab business from the City, saying: This is about history, not about domestic interests.But Mr Macron added: Im not the one to decide such a move and I do respect the choice of British voters.So I dont want to interfere in this debate about a second referendum and so on.He also took aim at the Leave campaign which won the 2016 referendum - suggesting Brits had been misled by politicians such as Boris Johnson and Michael Gove.The president said: It costs a lot, it’s much more complicated than they initially thought.Mr Macron has come under fire from Brexit campaigners for his efforts to overturn the referendum.And hes accused of deliberately setting out to punish the UK for quitting the EU in the hope of turning voters against Brexit.The ex-Home Secretary insisted No Deal would be such a disaster that shed rather see a peoples vote instead.She has previously been fiercely loyal to the PM - and is a firm supporter of Mrs Mays Chequers plan for Brexit.Ms Rudd told ITVs Peston last night: I don’t think No Deal will happen.I think that  we cant get a negotiated deal that the Prime Minister brings back through Parliament then I think that we’re in completely uncharted territory constitutionally.But I do think it would be ironic indeed  we got a people’s vote because the more Brexit-y people in my party were unable to support the Prime Minister in her negotiated settlement and then they might not even get their Brexit.Asked  a second referendum would be better than No Deal, the senior MP replied: Absolutely.

title: mum baby decapitated botched birth doctor said ive fixed him
story: Laura Gallazzi was 25 weeks pregnant when she went into labour, with a top NHS doctor pulling the babys legs during the birth.But the babys head was detached from his body during the horric delivery, with his head still left in his mothers womb.The first-time mum was then forced to undergo a C-section to remove the head - which was sewn back on to the tragic tots body so she could hold him and say goodbye.Cradling the plush bear that holds her sons ashes, the mum revealed to BBC Radio Scotland her terror at seeing her sons body, unsure what she would be confronted with.She said: I thought I dont want to see him, dont bring him in here, because I didnt know what I was going to be looking at.The doctor said its alright. Her words were Ive fixed him.Since a tribunal into the 2014 delivery at Dundees Ninewells hospital in Dundee, Scotland, Laura has spoken out of how she could not forgive the consultant gynaecologist, Dr Vaishnavy Laxman, for Stevens death.The investigation found that while Dr Laxmans decision to proceed with a vaginal delivery instead of a C-section was a mistake, the medic was cleared to  to work.Traumatised Laura, 34, earlier told The Sun: She butchered my son. How could this happen in this day and age?”Only three babies in the world are known to have succumbed to such a sickening fate and Laura said: It’s like something from medieval times. I never imagined this would be my experience of birth.”Dr Laxman admitted she had tried “too hard” to deliver the tot and the tribunal said she had been wrong not to carry out the initial C-section. But it ruled the senior gynaecologist had been working in the “best interests” of the mum, and that she posed “no risk to patient safety”.The ordeal has taken a huge toll on haunted Laura who now suffers post-traumatic stress disorder.The mum now keeps Stevens ashes in a teddy so she can have him with her — and on her forearm has tattoo prints of his hands and feet as well as the roman numerals of the year he was born.She says: “Even though I wasn’t ever able to hold him, I can carry him with me wherever I go now. Where I go, the teddy goes. I draw enormous comfort from it and would be lost without it.”

title: im not a stand up comedian theresa may says as pm insists shes right not to try and charm the public
story: In an interview with her own MP James Cleverly she dismissed the idea she should show more of her personality in public.It comes after she hit the headlines for her repeated bouts of awkward dancing while on a trip to Africa last month.In an article for The House magazine Mr Cleverly, the Tory party vice chairman, asked why she chose not to show more of her cheeky, humorous, slightly irreverent side in public.Mrs May replied: I was tempted to say that there are some people who would say that maybe the dancing in Africa was a side that they havent seen before – but there have been dferences of opinion as to whether that was a good thing to do!She added: Im not a stand-up comedian. I am Prime Minister.Elsewhere in the interview she said female MPs across the political ide had really suffered online.Asked whether women were being put off politics by abusive comments on social media the PM Minister said: It doesnt in terms of me personally, it doesnt distract me.But I am conscious that there are some of my female colleagues, across the House – it isnt a party thing – but across the House, colleagues have really suffered online and continue to suffer online.“Obviously weve had some instances investigated by the police and so forth.”She added: But it is a real problem that this nastiness, this sort of vicious streak has entered into our politics. I think that will put women off.Mrs May also pushed back when her Conservative colleague asked how much influence her husband has on her political decision.She said: I just wondered when you asked me about Philips role, whether  I was a male Prime Minister you would have asked the same question about their we?”Speaking to the Spectator magazine he said: “She said to the party that she will remain leader for as long as they want her to and I think at the moment people are absolutely backing her.”Pressed on whether he personally wants her to stay he replied: “She will decide, in due course, what she wants to do.“But now, she is focusing on the task in hand.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyn michel barnier brussels brexit
story: The Labour leaders aide had to make an urgent appeal for cash after realising no one was able to pay for the cab in Brussels this afternoon.Mr Corbyn was left waiting outside EU headquarters as his staff had a whip-round - and risked being late for his meeting with top eurocrat Michel Barnier.He told Mr Barnier, the EUs Brexit envoy, that Britain cant quit the EU without a trade deal lined up.The talks are a fresh bid to undermine the official Brexit negotiations being carried out by Theresa May.Mr Corbyn drew up at the office of the European Commission in a taxi with Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer.But the driver apparently refused to go in to the buildings vehicle entrance until he was paid - and he didnt accept cards.A Labour aide, Jack McKenna, was heard asking, Does anyone have any euros?Mr Corbyns right-hand man Seumas Milne laughed as another aide stepped in to provide the money needed.Mr McKenna took the incident in good humour - he tweeted afterwards: Brussels taxis accepting card payments just became Labour’s seventh Brexit test and must now be at the heart of any future deal.Labours fresh attempt to sideline Mrs May in Brussels comes after Labour opened the door to a second referendum on Brexit at their party conference this week.Mr Corbyn took Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer with him on the trip to Brussels today.Speaking after the meting, he said: Weve had an interesting, useful discussion with Mr Barnier.We have set out the views of the Labour Party surrounding Brexit following the conference speeches made by Keir Starmer and myself.We are obviously not negotiating. We are not in government, we are the opposition. But he was interested to know what our views are and the six tests we have laid down by which we will hold our government in future.The Labour boss refused to say whether Mr Barnier had backed Labours plan - which would keep the UK in the European customs union - over Theresa Mays.He said it would be going over the line to press the eurocrat on his views.Mr Corbyn said last night: “Crashing out of Europe with no deal risks being a national disaster.That is why I’m meeting EU officials today, and I will be urging them to do all they can to avoid a No Deal outcome, which would be so damaging to jobs and living standards in both the UK and EU countries.”The PM has repeatedly insisted that Britain must be prepared for a No Deal scenario.Otherwise the EU will be able to force us to accept whatever deal they want.Mr Corbyn is keen to keep Britain in the European customs union after Brexit - even though that would stop us cutting trade deals around the world.And at the Labour conference, activists voted for a new policy which could see the party backing a second referendum  Mrs May refuses to hold a General Election.Mr Barnier has previously met with a string of pro-EU politicians from Britain, who have lobbied him not to accept the PMs Brexit plans.

title: man makes mistake girlfriends moonpig card
story: Ryan Smith assured girlfriend Laura McKay he had made her a good one this year after she complained about him sending her cards late on her past two birthdays.The lad spent time adding in lots of personal snaps of the couples relationship together into a collage on the card companys website.But when long-suffering Laura opened up the card she was surprised to find it addressed to Georgia.Ryan - who Laura admits lacks common sense - had forgotten to change the template name on the card from Georgia to Laura.Laura thought shed missed a joke and asked: Are you kidding?Laura eventually understood what had happened - and found it so funny she called her mum in to have a look.Speaking to Unilad, Laura said: He does try his best with absolutely everything but sometimes his lack of common sense gets in the way.This is the most him thing possible. He was so excited to give me the card and it was just so funny because he tried so hard. I couldn’t even be angry at him.I shouted my mum in and told her about it and she couldn’t stop laughing.It’s up on my window ledge because I love the pictures on it.Ryans mum had even warned her son to check the card before handing it over.Laura said: He hands me it in the same envelope that it got delivered to his house in – even though it comes with two as you’re meant to open it, CHECK IT and put it in a fresh envelope.Might I add when it got delivered to his house, his mum said to him maybe you should check it but he was adamant it was perfect.”Laura should count herself lucky that it was her and Ryan’s faces smiling back from the card and not a photo of his genitals.Moonpig yesterday told customers to stop uploading pictures of their private parts and sending them in to be made into customised cards.

title: steven seagal run governor russia vladivostok
story: The 66-year-old action movie star was granted Russian citizenship by his close friend Vladimir Putin and regularly appears on television in the country.He was asked at a film festival in Vlaostok about his political ambitions and replied that he would like to run to Primorsky region.New elections have been declared in the far eastern region, where Vlaostok is the biggest city, following a disputed election earlier this month.My father’s family is from here. Every time I come here, I want to see more of the Primorsky Krai and become your Governor, the official TASS news agency reported him as saying.Vladimir Putin presented a Russian passport to Seagal in 2016.The Russian president said he hoped it would serve as a symbol of how fractious ties between Moscow and Washington were starting to improve.Putin personally presented the Hollywood star, whose father’s parents emigrated from Russia, with a passport at the Kremlin.The Russian Foreign Ministry likened Seagals new role to that of a UN goodwill ambassador and said that the actor, who is known for his martial arts prowess, would receive no salary.The gubernatorial election was held in Primorsky in early September but both candidates accused each other of violating the law.Russia’s Central Election Commission recommended the election’s results be cancelled due to vote rigging and the impossibility of identying the will of voters.According to TASS, Seagal would have to relinquish both his United States and Serbian citizenship, which he also obtained in 2016.Earlier this year, Seagal was accused of rape and sexual assault just weeks after being accused of being a sex pest.Regina Simons was an 18-year-old extra on the set of Seagal’s 1994 film “Deadly Ground” when she alleges that he raped her in his home.Simons claimed that Seagal, now 65, invited her to what he said was a wrap party for the film.But when she arrived, she said she was the only other person there.When she asked him where everyone else went, she says, Seagal told her that they’d already left.

title: theresa may conservative party capitalism
story: In an astonishing eve of party conference blast, Sam Gymiah said the Government had to offer a compelling capitalist vision to voters and stop trying to “out-Corbyn, Corbyn”.The Minister – who sits in both the Departments for Education and Business – stormed: “whichever side you are on in the Brexit debate, we need to realise that  we are not the party of business then we are nothing.”Speaking to House magazine, Mr Gyimah said that the Tories had been wrong to try and respond to Labour’s rhetoric.He said the Government gave the impression of “wanting to take on the mantle of Trumpian economic nationalism and protectionism”.And he instead urged Theresa May to align with business, and “make the case for reinvigorating capitalism”.“When we Conservatives veer between talking business down, ignoring voters’ concerns, and telling businesses to shut up – or worse – it is clear sign we have lost our way,” he said.The attack came just hours after former Minister Rob Halfon urged Theresa May to take notice of the “serious” offer from Labour – and do more for Britain’s struggling workers.It follows a spate of similar high-profile attacks from rising Tories such as Treasury Minister Liz Truss and Tory deputy chair James Cleverly.Ms Truss used a speech in the US earlier this month to insist the Tories stop “apologising for backing enterprise”.Mr Cleverly last week urged the party to give the public “something positive” to vote for.Theresa May has slapped a price cap on the energy sector as part of a campaign to fix “broken markets”.And ex-Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson sparked uproar in the summer after it emerged he snapped “f***” business in a rant at the CBI over Brexit.In his article, Mr Gyimah stormed: “When it comes to our relationship with business, we must unscramble our compass  we are to stand any chance of defeating the hard left.”He added: “We need to be honest about the failings of capitalism, while making the case that it’s the best system we’ve got. Attacking Labour and proclaiming our sound economic management is necessary but not sufficient.“I can’t help thinking we have lost our way. Disconcerted by a sht in the zeitgeist against business, and by the cumulative surprises of the financial crisis, the EU referendum and the 2017 general election, we appear to have become confused about how to handle business.“We are at our best when we are pro-enterprise and pro-endeavour, and when we do this in a way that is clear that our motive is to make the world a better place and improve the lot of ordinary citizens.“To succeed we need to offer a compelling alternative vision that the next generation can buy into.“We can’t out-Corbyn Corbyn, and  we try, we risk offering a pale imitation that leaves people yearning for the real thing.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: renters abandon tories housing
story: A new survey of the 60 tighest constituency battlefields shows barely a quarter – 28% - of the key voting group living in them now back Theresa May’s party. Half – 50% - now plan to vote for Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour party instead.The findings – by pollsters Number Cruncher Politics for the housing charity Shelter – suggest soaring rents and sky high house prices are now an even bigger issue in deciding who will run the country than at the last general election.The poll also reveals that Labour has now leapfrogged the Tories to take a 2 point lead in the marginals among all voters, by 42% v 40%.That reverses the result at last year’s general election where the Tories narrowly came out on top across the 60 tightest races, by 46% v 44% - meaning the party has shed six per of its support in 16 months.All voters in the marginals say they are also now more pessimistic about the state of housing than any other issue.Two thirds of them - 67% - think the cost and availability of housing has got worse over the past five years.In comparison the number worried about rising crime is 66%, those troubled by falling healthcare standards , rising immigration levels , and the poorer quality of schools .Private renters also back an increase in the number of council houses being built over policies to help with homeownership, the poll also found.A total of 39% of them in the marginal said the government should prioritise building more social housing, compared to only 31% who preferred controversial schemes such as Help to Buy.Number Cruncher Politics’s boss Matt Singh said: “Housing was key to last year’s general election result, with renters – and particularly private renters – fuelling the increase in turnout and swing to Labour that cost the Conservatives their majority.“The poll shows that housing is both important to voters in crucial marginal seats, and something they feel particularly gloomy about.“These findings sound a warning to the Tories ahead of their conference.”In what experts dubbed a ‘rentquake’, there was a huge boost in turnout among enraged private renters at the nationwide poll last year.Three in ten renters who voted Tory in 2015 – 29% - abandoned the party in 2017, with three-quarters of them defecting to Labour.Shelter CEO Polly Neate said the research should “set alarm bells ringing for MPs”.Ms Neate added: “Key voters are very pessimistic about the housing crisis, and private renters in particular look like they pose a threat at the ballot box. But there are options on the table to get out of this mess.“As the numbers show, instead of pumping more cash into failed ideas like Help to Buy, we should be building much more social housing to give hard-pressed families an alternative to the private rented sector.“Not only would this be a massive stride towards ending this crisis, but it’d be wildly popular too – so let’s get on with it.”Between 2001 and 2018 the size of the private rental sector doubled, from 11% of the adult population to 28%.The same period also saw a marked decline in the number who own their own home, falling from 73% of the population to 59%.The Tories are consumed by Brexit. But away from that they must wake up and present radical ideas to beat ­Corbyn’s, especially on housing.They have an advantage.Theirs are more likely to be sane.And vanishingly less likely to put hundreds of thousands on the dole.But Theresa May must realise that voters have more pressing problems than Brexit which could cost her power.Next week the Tories must have a new story to tell.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pm nypd aides stranded
story: The PM’s  flight from the UN General Assembly in the Big Apple was delayed by an hour due to the hiccup.Eleven senior advisors were travelling in a bus in the PM’s motorcade to JFK airport when its gear box packed up.The bus was stuck blocking two lanes of traffic for about half an hour before a replacement bus was found.And three police officers in a NYPD squad car escorted them to the airport.But the PM made them sweat by pretending to set a six-minute deadline to arrive - otherwise she would order the pilot to take off without them.Her chief of joined in - telling them take-off was imminent.The top aides - who included deputy national security advisor Christian Turner, head of operations Richard Tricky” Jackson and her senior spin doctors - were already looking up alternative flights home.But Mrs May welcomed them onto the plane in person when they arrived nearly an hour later than her - and led a round of applause.She invited the three NYPD police officers up the steps for a photo.A Downing Street source said: “New York’s finest rescued the PM’s team from the side of the freeway and got us to the runway for the flight home. “Just another way to deepen the special relationship, and we’re very grateful for their help.”The bus broke down while travelling in the fast lane as part of the PM’s motorcade from downtown Manhattan to JFK airport.Cars were flying by at speeds of more than 40mph. One of the aides said: “It was pretty hairy stuff.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: motor groups argue fuel duty hike
story: FairFuelUK will meet Treasury Secretary Robert Jenrick on October 9 – amid fears the Chancellor is about to rubber stamp the first increase in the tax for EIGHT YEARS.It comes as sources claim hauliers are preparing to “drive on Parliament” in protest at sky-high petrol prices.Separately, new figures from FairFuel show that struggling Brits are spending up to 25 per cent of their hard-earned cash on filling up their car.Nearly 4 per cent of Brits on £25,000 spend 25 per cent or more on petrol, while nearly a third spend between 15-25 per cent.Other findings from the poll of 71,000 motorists show that 67 per cent of people have “categorically no choice” but to use their car every day.Speaking last night, FairFuel UK co-founder Howard Cox said: “It’s time the Treasury listened to the ‘just about managing’ and got in touch with reality.“Don’t hit those in the pocket who will decide the next Government.It would be political suicide.”Fuel duty has been frozen ever since the Sun’s ‘Keep it Down’ campaign launched in Spring 2011.Chancellor Philip Hammond on Wednesday announced this year’s Budget willtake place on October 29. The early date means it can take place before any potential row with Eurosceptics over the Brexit deal with Brussels.Speaking last month, the Chancellorover the rest of the decade could generate an extra £38 billion for the Treasury.Fuel duty in the UK is among the highest in Europe, at nearly 60p of the pump price.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: beluga whale thames stay months
story: The Beluga, which is normally used to swimming in Arctic waters, was first spotted on Tuesday morning between Gravesend and Tilbury in the River Thames.British Divers Marine Le Rescue Director Geoff Hammock and Thames region coordinator Sam Lipman used a Rigid Inflatable Boat  to get close to the Beluga whale.Mr Hammock said: It is as well as can be expected.We think it is feeding.He added: “We think that  there was not any food it would have been looking for food.It keeps coming back to the same point.But Ms Lipman said the whale could stay in the Thames “for weeks or months  he or she is happy feeding.”She added: We are looking at body condition and behaviour.We are just going on what we can observe.It looks like it could be a sub-adult, it has grey tinges.There have only been about 20 reports in British waters so it is a really rare occurrence.The whale, which is believed to be up to three metres long, was spotted at 10:30am on the Kent side on Thursday morning.Richard Sabin, a whale expert from Londons Natural History Museum, previously said: Belugas eat a wide iety of prey and this will increase this animals survival chances.”Its good news he appears to be feeding well because he will stand a greater chance of ing north to his normal habitat  he can stay strong.A spokesman for ORCA added: “The experts on the ground are monitoring closely and  the situation changes plans are in place to respond quickly and effectively.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
