title: children-were-left-screaming-for-help-in-hot-car
story: Andrew Yorkston left the youngsters in the back seat of his car with the windows fully rolled up for about 30 minutes on a hot summer&rsquos day.  The girl and the boy were trapped in the locked vehicle and were only rescued after passers-by heard the traumatised girl screaming &ldquohelp, save us.  The concerned passer-by contacted the police and managed to calm the distraught children down by waiting by the vehicle while it was parked in a lay-by near to Prestonpans last year.  Yorkston, who was in charge of the children&rsquos welfare, eventually appeared about 30 minutes later claiming he had &ldquoonly been five minutes and had been relieving himself.  The 28-year-old then jumped into his car and drove away from the lay-by, leaving the police to launch a hunt for him and the two children.  Yorkston had previously admitted abandoning the children in the car last August when he appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court earlier this year and he was due back in the dock last Wednesday.  Solicitor Cameron Tait, defending, said that his client had not attended court but asked Sherf Adrian Cottam to deal with the case in his absence.  Mr Tait added that the care of the children was now under supervision of the local social work department.  Sherf Cottam agreed and decided to admonish Yorkston on the charge of abandoning the children.  Previously, the court heard that the two children were spotted within the locked vehicle parked at a lay-by on the B1361 at about 5.30pm on August 16 last year.  Fiscal depute Mark Keane said: &ldquoWitnesses were out for a walk and they observed a stationary car in the lay-by and saw two children within the car who very distressed.  &ldquoThe girl was shouting &lsquohelp, save us&rsquo.  When asked where the person looking after her was, the girl pointed to an opening in the trees.  The fiscal added that &ldquothe car was locked and the windows were fully up and it was &ldquoa hot day.  &ldquoThe witnesses became concerned about the children&rsquos welfare and decided to phone the police and stay with the car for about 25 minutes, the fiscal added.  Solicitor Lesley Cunningham, defending, told the court that Yorkston had stopped for a toilet break as he took the children to a McDonald&rsquos restaurant.  Ms Cunningham said that her client had &ldquoan underlying drug problem at the time of the incident which was &ldquonow resolved.  She added: &ldquoMr Yorkston was taking the children to a McDonald&rsquos and stopped by the side of the road for the toilet. He admits now this was foolish in the extreme. Fortunately there was no harm done to the children.  Yorkston admitted to being responsible for two children and wilfully abandoning them by leaving them alone within a locked vehicle while windows were fully closed in hot weather conditions at a lay-by on the B1361 near to Prestonpans on August 16 last year.

title: popular-former-musselburgh-church-minister-is-remembered
story: The American-born clergyman served Musselburgh Congregational Church, on Links Street, for 41 years after being inducted as its minister in 1968.  A bachelor, he retired to Gford in 2009.  With the help of neighbours and friends he remained at home until April, when his growing frailty led to him being admitted to Midlothian Community Hospital.  Just two weeks before he died, Mr Lindgren was moved to Herdmanflat Hospital in Haddington until a permanent home could be found but he passed away on July 18.  Mr Lindgren was born in Lynn, Massachusetts, on May 28, 1930 his father Raymond was Swedish and his mother Effie was a Macleod from the isle of Skye.  Mr Lindgren was ordained into church ministry in 1957 at the age of 27, holding a list of degrees including a Bachelor of Arts, Bachelor of Theology, Master of Theology and PhD.  He was inducted into the Ministry of Genoa Congregational Church in Nebraska, where he served for six years.  With practical experience under his belt, he went on to complete a post-graduate degree at New College Edinburgh before arriving in Musselburgh, where he took an avid interest in community le.  The Rev Janice Andrews, minister at Musselburgh Congregational Church, said: &ldquoHe was one of the longest-serving members of Musselburgh Rotary Club.  &ldquoWhen Musselburgh hosted the district conference he was charged with preaching to 1,000 delegates &ndash an onerous task but members had complete confidence in his ability to speak to such a large audience, he was so very competent.  &ldquoFor over 20 years of his ministry he served as chaplain to the 297 Musselburgh Squadron RAF Air Cadets.  &ldquoHe had a keen interest in antiques and collected old postcards.  &ldquoHe used this collection to publish an illustrated history of the towns and villages of East Lothian and the city of Edinburgh, evidence of his sincere interest in this beautul and historic area of Scotland.  She added: &ldquoDonald handled the Gospel with truth and diligence. His sermons were always topical, he was knowledgeable, articulate and had the ability to keep his hearers engaged.  &ldquoHis ministry was inclusive. He made everyone welcome whether they came regularly or very occasionally, he was always encouraging and approachable.  &ldquoHe procured a beautul organ built by George Holdrich in the late 1800s for a church in Appleby in the Lake District which was due to be scrapped.  &ldquoDonald had it restored and installed in Musselburgh Congregational Church, where it continues to rouse worshippers today.  Mr Lindgren&rsquos funeral at Musselburgh Congregational Church and Seafield Crematorium was well attended by the community of Musselburgh and Fisherrow.  Representatives from many organisations he was associated with, including Musselburgh Rotary Club, Musselburgh Air Cadets and Fisherrow Yacht Club, were present to pay their last respects.

title: plea-for-volunteers-to-join-the-team-at-musselburgh-cab
story: Claire Grehan, volunteer support officer, said sometimes there could be three or four volunteer advisers on duty but the busy High Street office was down to just one that day. The restricted service was only for general advice, which makes up about a quarter of the total bureau work, but paid staff were still available for case work and outreach services as normal.  Claire said: &ldquoI think a lot of people don&rsquot know that CAB is a volunteer-based charity, so we do rely on volunteers to be on reception, to become general advisers and also some of them do administrative work as well.  She said that volunteers were often people who were retired but wanted to keep mentally active, those who were between jobs and wanted to build new skills, and law students looking for experience.  Claire, who also handles financial capability issues at the CAB, started out as a volunteer adviser.  She said: &ldquoWe always need volunteers, who are the leblood of the CAB.  &ldquoWe have about 30 [volunteers] at the moment and 12 members of staff.  &ldquoWe put a lot into advisers and helping them but not everyone makes it at the other end.  &ldquoAs volunteers they can also take holidays whenever they want or attend appointments but it is important that we get a certain level of commitment.  She added: &ldquoGeneral advisers deal with everything from the dog next door barking too loudly to entitlement to benefits.  &ldquoThey also deal with dismissal cases, as well as helping people to make phone calls and write letters.  &ldquoAround 35 per cent of the cases will be about benefits and about 20 per cent on debt followed by employment, housing, customer and local issues.  The CAB&rsquos other volunteer support officer, Magdalena Szulc, who also began as a volunteer, agreed with her colleague.  She said: &ldquoWe need people who can commit for six to seven hours&rsquo volunteering each week and the training programme, which can take six to eight months.  &ldquoThey also need good listening skills, to work well in teams, be open-minded, don&rsquot judge people or their circumstances and enjoy helping people.  She interviews the recruits, who, after initial training, get to &lsquoshadow&rsquo a general adviser before going it alone with support from the session supervisor.  Musselburgh resident Andrew Aitken decided to become a volunteer adviser a year and a half ago as, even although he works, he found he had some free time on his hands.  He said: &ldquoIt is interesting and is good  you can be of some use to people.  &ldquoI&rsquom at the CAB for half a day twice a week.  The next adviser training programme starts on Thursday, October 4.  Anyone interested in getting involved should pick up an application form from the CAB, which is located on High Street.  Alternatively, email info@musselburghcab.casonline.org.uk, phone 0131 653 2748 or go to the Musselburgh CAB&rsquos website musselburghcab.org.uk

title: youtube-and-wikipedia-edit-a-thon-event-for-preston-tower
story: Dig It! TV is planning to bring eight Scottish castles and towers into the digital age by touring round them, and then holding &lsquoedit-a-thons&rsquo where the castles&rsquo Wikipedia pages will be updated and improved.  The tower, at Prestonpans, will be visited by Dig It! TV presenter David Weinczok &ndash known as &lsquothe Castle Hunter&rsquo &ndash who will film a walking tour of the historic building which will be released as part of an eight-video series on Wednesday.  Dr Jeff Sanders, project manager at Dig It!, said of the Preston Tower edit-a-thon: &ldquoYouTube and Wikipedia are two of the most popular websites in the world, which makes them the perfect place to inspire the next generation of castle enthusiasts.  &ldquoWe&rsquore looking forward to shining a spotlight on some of these lesser-known but equally fascinating sites.  The event is funded by the Castle Studies Trust, and Jeremy Cunnington, chair of trustees, said: &ldquoThe Castle Studies Trust is delighted to have funded these videos as it raises these important &ndash but not well enough known &ndash castles.  &ldquoThe videos will hopefully encourage visitors to these sites and show how these &ndash and all the other castles in Scotland &ndash play an important part in Scottish history and heritage.  The other venues visited are in Midlothian, Fe, South Ayrshire and the Borders.  There will be two &lsquoedit-a-thons&rsquo events &ndash part of Scotland&rsquos Archaeology Month &ndash which will held at the Riverside Museum in Glasgow on Tuesday and then the Engine Shed in Stirling next Friday .  Dr Sara Thomas, Scotland programme coordinator for Wikimedia UK, will be present at the events, overseeing the volunteers and helping guide them as they edit the pages of little-known Scottish castles. Dig It! TV is part of the Dig It! project, which is co-ordinated by the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland and primarily funded by Historic Environment Scotland.

title: bid-to-modernise-dunbar-cement-plant-set-to-get-under-way
story: Tarmac Cement and Lime Limited asked the local authority&rsquos planning department to consider ious proposals which would form part of &ldquoa continued drive to improve efficiency and sustainability at the business, to the east of the town.  Dunbar Cement Plant, which employs more than 140 people and contributes &pound8 million to the local economy each year, has now been given the go-ahead to create a cement mill grinding station, storage silo and ious other facilities.  According to the planning officer&rsquos report: &ldquoIn a supporting statement submitted with the application it is stated that the proposal is part of Tarmac&rsquos long-term internal upgrade and modernisation programme at Dunbar cement works.  &ldquoIt asserts that the cement mill is necessary to produce new grades of cement required for modern construction and the cement market.  &ldquoThe proposed mill will replace two existing mills on the site and will be more energy-efficient and quieter than those existing mills.  &ldquoThe supporting statement also asserts that the cement works benefits from rail sidings on both the south and north side of the East Coast Mainline.  &ldquoTrains run under a load out structure that feeds cement into rail tankers.  &ldquoAt present, trains are fed only on the south side using adjacent silos where train capacity is already fully used.  &ldquoAdditional products must therefore be exported by road.  &ldquoUntil the late 1980s, the northern siding was also fed by a large silo that was dismantled. It is now proposed to reinstate a modern silo on this side to increase rail capacity.  Oliver Curtin, Dunbar Cement Plant manager, was pleased that permission had been granted, with further permissions to be secured before work gets under way, with staff levels to remain the same.  He said: &ldquoWe&rsquore pleased that East Lothian Council has approved our application to upgrade the facilities at Dunbar.  &ldquoThe plans will allow us to bring the latest technology to our operations, build on our offer to customers and maximise use of the rail network for transportation across Scotland and England.  &ldquoWe will now work with the Scottish Environment Protection Agency to secure appropriate operating permits.  &ldquoOnce the necessary environmental permissions are in place, we will create a detailed plan for construction and operational timescales.

title: maria-lyles-achievements-recognised-at-scottish-parliament
story: Maria Lyle became a six-time European champion after clinching gold in the T35 100m at the World Para-athletics European Championships last month.  The 18-year-old, who has cerebral palsy, then spoke about her struggle with her mental health over the last year.  Iain Gray, East Lothian MSP, highlighted the teenager&rsquos achievements at Holyrood, where a number of his colleagues also backed his praise of the former Dunbar Grammar School pupil.  The motion reads: &ldquoThat the Parliament congratulates 18-year-old Maria Lyle, who is from Dunbar, on successfully defending her T35 100m European title at the World Para Athletics European Championships in Berlin notes that Maria already has three Paralympic medals, six European titles, a Commonwealth silver and five World medals, which it considers a remarkable achievement for such a young athlete commends Maria on her determination and commitment to athletics and her decision to speak publicly about the pressures and dficulties that she has faced as young elite athlete, and the impact it has had on her personal le and mental health, and believes that Maria is a fantastic role model for young people in Scotland.  Maria&rsquos decision to comment on mental health was widely praised.  The Dunbar teenager, who pulled out of the event&rsquos 200m race through injury, said: &ldquoI have had a tough year and struggled with my mental health.  &ldquoI have had a few dficult years and when you don&rsquot perform it can eat you up as a person when you expect so much.

title: north-berwick-in-bloom-chairwoman-rosie-oberlander-to-stand-down
story: Rosemary Oberlander will resign from her role at the group&rsquos AGM in November.  Mrs Oberlander, known as Rosie, has been a volunteer for the best part of two decades and at the helm for nearly eight years, but has decided to stand aside to focus more time on her painting career.  She told the Courier she had &ldquoloved everything about the role.  &ldquoThe whole experience has been great fun and I have learned a lot &ndash not just about gardening &ndash in that time, she said. &ldquoI&rsquove also met some really great people and I&rsquom sure that [North Berwick In Bloom] will continue just fine once I&rsquove stood down.  The York Road resident does, though, hope to remain involved in some capacity.  Mrs Oberlander added: &ldquoI will retain my involvement with school pupils but have decided I need more time to devote to my painting career.  &ldquoI would like to thank everyone for their support over the years and wish the team and my successor, whoever that may be, good luck.  And she picked out last year&rsquos Rosebowl win at the Beautul Scotland awards as a highlight of her tenure  &ldquoTo be chosen as the best in Scotland was is a great thing, she said.  But the 52-year-old also said the praise of local residents &ldquomeans just as much to her.  She added: &ldquoIt really isn&rsquot about winning awards, it&rsquos about the taking part.  &ldquoIt means as much to me when people stop me in the street and tell me how great the town is looking.  &ldquoTo know that the people of North Berwick appreciate what we do is lovely.  And she said that winning their latest gold award &ndash in the coastal town category at last Thursday&rsquos awards &ndash was a nice way to bow out, adding: &ldquoI&rsquove had a good run but I&rsquod made my mind up [to stand down] before the awards.  A spokesperson for the horticultural group added: &ldquoRosie will be hard to follow.  &ldquoShe has been much more than a chairwoman.

title: faith-harvey-aiming-to-go-to-muay-thai-world-championships
story: Lewis Inglis, 15, and Faith Harvey, 12, are rising stars on the Scottish Muay Thai scene with both holding ious belts.  Lewis, of Dalkeith, is the current WTKA Scottish Champion, Sandee Open Intercontinental British Champion, Yokkao Open British Champion and SUSU Fighting Championship Champion. As a result, he is also British No. 1 and No. 2 in two weight isions.  Faith, of Tranent, is current Yokkao Scottish Champion, WTKA British Champion, Yokkao Open British K1 Champion, and Celtic Nations Champion and is ranked No. 2 in the UK.  In Italy, the duo will be competing to become both WTKA Muay Thai and K1 world champions.  Scott Hendry founded the club with friend Charles Cameron in 2014, and currently trains both Lewis and Faith.  "Definitely, we could have two world champions coming back in November," he told the Courier.  "They could come back with both titles which would be a tremendous achievement."  Faith's exploits are all the more impressive considering she has only been in the sport since May 2017.  "Faith has been pretty remarkable," Scott said. "She's had eleven fights in the space of a year.  "She's won four titles and she's ranked number two in the UK.  "She's fought the girl who is ranked number one four times and beat her three times.  "I've calculated it and she should move to number one by the end of the year."  The club, who train in the Bronx Boxing Gym in Tranent, will hold a fundraiser on Sunday, October 14.  He said: "We're actually going to be fundraising in the gym.  "We're inviting gyms from all over Scotland to come in and spar in the ring and it'll be &pound3/4 on the door to come in.  "All proceeds from that will go to the trip. Then we've got the JustGiving page as well."  Muay Thai is Thailand's national sport but the WTKA Unied World Championships will be held in Carrara, between Pisa and Genoa, over October and November.  It was recognised as a provisional Olympic sport in 2016 meaning it will receive funding just under &pound20,000 in annual funding from the International Olympic Committee.  The sport can then apply to become part of the Olympic games sports programme after three years.  Speaking about the championship and Olympic approval, Scott said: "I think its good for the whole of the sport to be honest.  "That's a huge thing for the sport, it should open up other avenues for the sport in terms of funding, as well as increase the profile of the sport."  There's definite potential for both Lewis and Faith to become Olympic athletes but Scott knows there is a long road ahead  both want to go pro.  "Lewis is in a predicament because he's really good at football as well. He goes across to train in Glasgow every two weeks with the Scotland Youth Development squad.  "So, there's a chance Lewis could go into pro football, teams have spoken to him. He's going to have a choice to make at some point.  "With Faith, I think  it's done right she could make a career out of it.  "There's avenues she could look at going down, but she's only 12 so there's a long way to go just yet."  The club has also recently been nominated three times in the Celebrating Sports Awards, held by East Lothian Council.  Put forward by Councillor and Provost John McMillan, they are shortlisted in three categories: Performance/Development Coach of the Year, Club or Community Coach of the Year, and Sports Club of the Year.  It follows on from their Junior Team of the Year award, which they received in April.  To donate to Lewis and Faith's cause, visit: www.justgiving/crowdfunding/blackdiamond-thaiboxingclub

title: lifeboat-volunteer-recognised-for-20-years-of-lifesaving-work
story: Mark Anderson joined the leboat crew, based at the town&rsquos harbour, in 1998 after moving to the town from Grangemouth to work at Tarmac&rsquos cement plant on the outskirts of Dunbar.  Since then, the 58-year-old has risen to the position of second coxswain and become a key part of the station.  Mark, who has no intention of calling it a day just yet, said: &ldquoWhen I joined the RNLI I never thought I&rsquod see so much of the country and coastline and it gives me great pride to think of the shouts I&rsquove been on and the people I&rsquove been able to help.  &ldquoThere have been some great times and some sad moments, which you have to cope with, but on the whole I have thoroughly enjoyed it.  &ldquoAlthough my family didn&rsquot have a maritime background, I have always been into boats and,  I had my time again, I might well have taken a job that allowed me to go to sea.  &ldquoBeing part of the leboat crew has given me a chance to do something for the community. You have to make sacrices but it&rsquos been worth it.  Mark, who retired last year from being a dispatch clerk at the cement works, plans to continue with the role he loves &ndash helping those in trouble &ndash with the RNLI.  He described the voluntary position as &ldquomore than just a hobby and said that he always looked forward to the weekly training exercises.  Mark, who lives near the harbour, said: &ldquoWhen I got transferred here I thought about joining the Coastguard.  &ldquoI wanted to do something and had always been keen on the sea and thought about joining the Coastguard.  &ldquoI met a member of the leboat crew and they said to come down and the rest is history.  Since then, Mark has been involved in dozens of rescues on both the inshore leboat  and the all-weather leboat.  Gary Fairbairn, Dunbar coxswain, paid tribute to his colleague&rsquos service.  He said: &ldquoIt&rsquos been an honour to serve with Mark for 20 years through thick and thin and he deserves this recognition.  Mark was recently presented with his long-service badge at the station.  He joins fellow crew members Alistair Punton, second mechanic, deputy launching authority Denholm Horsburgh and Mr Fairbairn in reaching the milestone.

title: young-tennis-ace-rubs-shoulders-with-the-stars
story: Ben Krievs met Great Britain&rsquos Cameron Norrie and Uzbekistan&rsquos Sanjar Fayziev, ranked 516 in the world, at the net for the crucial fourth match in the international competition in Glasgow on Sunday.  Ben&rsquos mum, Emer, told the Courier her son was a keen tennis player and was delighted to be involved.  She said: &ldquoHe met the players and the referee and then had to do the coin toss. They introduced him over the tannoy and said how he had been playing since he was five years old. He plays for Dunbar Tennis Club and the East Lothian squad.  &ldquoThey asked who was his favourite player is, which is Andy Murray.  &ldquoCameron Norrie played against the Uzbek player and then Ben got pictures taken with Jamie Murray  and Dan Evans  and got some signed tennis balls.  &ldquoBen was pleased about that and was able to watch Cameron Norrie win the match.  &ldquoHe was quite excited and nervous as well. It is quite a big deal, with a big crowd and big stadium.  &ldquoHe was really pleased with himself and had practised to toss the coin and make sure he did not muck it up.  Nine-year-old Ben, who plays alongside his big brother Luke, was nominated for the role by coaches Thomas Swan and Kevin Duffy, from the East Lothian tennis squad.  The youngster has been playing since he was just five years old.  The two coaches put the Dunbar Primary School pupil forward because of his good attitude and commitment to the sport.  The trip to Glasgow&rsquos Emirates Arena, where Great Britain won 3-1 with Norrie, ranked 70 in the world, winning 6-2, 6-2, 6-0 to settle the encounter, gave Ben a taste of the big time, with the youngster playing in the East Lothian Open earlier this summer.  His mum added: &ldquoHe found it quite inspiring.  &ldquoJust to meet the players was inspiring and the whole atmosphere was very exciting.

title: duo-in-peak-condition-for-kilimanjaro-climb
story: Ruth Coates and Fern Mitchell have spent a year training for the gruelling challenge of climbing Mount Kilimanjaro and will set off on the nine-day journey tomorrow .  It means leaving behind their jobs and families as they look to raise thousands of pounds in vital funds for Children 1st, Scotland&rsquos national children&rsquos charity.  Ruth, who runs a counselling and psychotherapy business, knows all about the charity.  She said: &ldquoHaving previously worked as a Project Worker for Children 1st in their Midlothian service, I&rsquove seen first-hand the incredible work that the charity does to help young people and their families.  &ldquoIt was a very rewarding,  not challenging, experience, but I&rsquove been committed to continuing my support for Children 1st &ndash it&rsquos something that is very close to my heart.  &ldquoWhen the opportunity arose to take part in the Mount Kilimanjaro challenge, I jumped at the chance.  &ldquoI wanted to do something dferent and a bit adventurous to mark my 40th birthday, so I thought &lsquolet&rsquos just go for it!&rsquo  Already, Ruth, of Dunbar, has raised more than &pound6,300 and is hoping to reach &pound7,000 by the time she s from the challenge to her husband Lawson Auden and children Nuala, 8, and five-year-old Rowan.  She added: &ldquoNow the challenge is closing in, I&rsquom feeling a healthy combination of nervousness and excitement.  &ldquoI&rsquom going to find it dficult being away from my family, especially my two children but I&rsquom excited for this new experience, especially seeing the starlit Tanzanian night sky, and of course, reaching the top of the summit!  &ldquoI can&rsquot thank my friends and family enough for all their support so far, I hope I can do them all proud.  The duo will be joined by nine other Scots as they aim to fly the charity flag from the plateau after a 19,341-feet endurance climb to raise funds to support children and their families who have faced trauma across Scotland.  Twenty-four-year-old Fern, of North Berwick, has already collected &pound1,800 and is aiming to more than double that by the end of the year.  The former North Berwick High School pupil, who is a participation officer at Lacrosse Scotland, told the Courier: &ldquoI truly believe that all children deserve the right to a fun, safe and healthy childhood.  &ldquoIn my role as chairwoman of the North Berwick Community and Surrounding Areas Sports Hub and at Lacrosse Scotland, I see how sport can help children set goals, be motivated, learn disciplines and work in a team &ndash lelong skills that all children should have access to.  &ldquoI&rsquove also witnessed how sport can be a child&rsquos safe haven when they are facing challenging times &ndash I&rsquom passionate about helping young people as much as possible through the power of sport.  &ldquoI&rsquom looking forward to not only the physical element but also the mental challenge as well.  &ldquoMy le motto is to &lsquobe the change you wish to see in the world&rsquo so that&rsquos why I&rsquom doing this.  &ldquoI would like to thank everyone who has donated so far and give a big shout out to my dogs  &ndash they have been the perfect training partners!  The money raised will help Children 1st&rsquos ongoing work to promote the safety and wellbeing of vulnerable children, young people and their families in Scotland by offering help and support to survivors of abuse, neglect and other childhood trauma.  After helping over 10,000 children, young people and family members last year alone, Children 1st aim to continue their prevention, protection and recovery work across Scotland.  Mary Glasgow, interim CEO at Children 1st, said: &ldquoWe&rsquore extremely grateful to Ruth, Fern and the team who have chosen to embark on this experience of a letime to raise crucial funds for Children 1st. It&rsquos been humbling to witness the great fundraising efforts the group have gone to already and to see them put themselves forward for such a physically and mentally challenging adventure.  To donate, visit Ruth's page here or Fern's fundraising page here&nbsp  For more information on the charity, visit www.children1st.org.uk.

title: racecourse-licence-is-extended-to-years-end
story: A further extension to its racing licence has been granted by the British Horseracing Authority .  The licence had been due to expire at the end of the flat season next month but it will now continue beyond the four jump fixtures planned for November and December.  The decision comes as East Lothian Council continues to look to appoint a third party to run the facility on its behalf.  The course&rsquos future had been in doubt following a breakdown in relations between the council and Musselburgh&rsquos racing representatives.  Councillor Fiona O&rsquoDonnell, chairwoman of Musselburgh Racecourse Associated Committee , said: &ldquoThis further extension of Musselburgh Racecourse&rsquos licence reflects the very positive work which has taken place to secure the track&rsquos future.  Four jump racing fixtures are planned between November 7 and December 10, with racing also taking place on New Year&rsquos Day.  The BHA board has extended the licence to cover the 2018 events and is conditional on a licence application being lodged with the national body, which is under way, and also keeping it updated on the progress of the procurement process to appoint a new operator.  Musselburgh Racecourse will apply for a racecourse licence for 2019 later this year.  Members of MRAC are aware the BHA may issue further temporary licences throughout 2019 while the process of appointing a third party to operate the racecourse is under way.  Ms O&rsquoDonnell added: &ldquoThe procurement process for appointing a third party operator is being progressed and I look forward to reporting further progress in due course.

title: lecture-held-in-memory-of-former-east-lothian-mp
story: John P Mackintosh was Berwick and East Lothian MP when he passed away in 1978, aged just 48.  His memory is honoured each year by the Mackintosh Memorial lecture, which alternates between East Lothian and the University of Edinburgh, where he was also Professor of Politics.  Mackintosh was a powerful advocate of Scottish devolution when that was an unpopular view in the Labour Party.  Marking the 40th anniversary of his death, the regular memorial lecture was replaced by a panel debate on &ldquoWhere Now for Democracy?, held in the Scottish Parliament&rsquos main chamber and chaired by Presiding Officer Ken McIntosh.  An audience of 200 heard contributions from Catherine Stihler MEP, Professor Mona Siddiqui, Baron Campbell  and Angus Robertson .  The event was followed by a reception in the Parliament, with contributions from Mackintosh&rsquos daughter Charlotte Barbour Professor Peter Mathieson, principal of the Universtiy of Edinburgh and East Lothian MSP Iain Gray.  The reception also saw the premiere of a video about Mackintosh directed by John Boothman, a booklet about his le, and an exhibition of material from the university&rsquos archives.  Mr Gray said: &ldquoThe JP Mackintosh Committee wanted to mark this anniversary in a way that would pay tribute to his signicant contribution to British politics and contribute to current political debate.  &ldquoThe panel debate at Holyrood brought together speakers from a range of dferent perspectives to consider the topic &lsquowhere now for democracy?&rsquo.  &ldquoIt was a lively and interesting debate and one which I think Mackintosh would have enjoyed.  &ldquoWhether it was promoting devolution for Scotland, pooling our sovereignty with our European neighbours, or his work as a Professor at Edinburgh University, democracy and how to strengthen it was very much at the centre of his political thought and action.  &ldquoThe issues Mackintosh was passionate about remain at the top of the political agenda 40 years on from his death.  &ldquoHis legacy is a powerful one and I&rsquom very pleased we were able to celebrate it in this way.

title: finish-line-nears-for-team-running-in-memory-of-much-missed-minister
story: Nine family members of the Rev Jenner Macrae &ndash known as Team Jenny &ndash have been taking on a series of gruelling challenges across Scotland and Northern Ireland.  The runners &ndash Jenner&rsquos sister Susan Gibson, along with the late minister&rsquos daughters Laura Burgess and Elaine Macrae, nieces Clare Furze and Kara Wallace, and granddaughters Ciara Burgess and Isla Burgess, as well as Laura&rsquos husband Barry and Kara&rsquos husband Duncan &ndash have been raising funds throughout the summer in aid of Edinburgh Maggie&rsquos Centre.  Jenner died on March 2, aged 63, having been minister of St Mary&rsquos Parish Church for more than a decade.  Only three more events remain, with the family&rsquos initial target of &pound1,000 smashed as nearly &pound7,000 has been raised.  Susan, who takes on the Scottish 10k &ndash which starts and finishes in Musselburgh on Sunday &ndash alongside Duncan, said: &ldquoWe are completely blown away by the generosity we have come across. It has been a really positive thing for us.  &ldquoYou just think the whole thing was completely ghastly and  something good can come out of it then that has got to be good.  &ldquoIt is what Jenner wanted and I think she would be chuffed to bits about the money we have raised.  Also this weekend, Barry takes on the Belfast City Half Marathon.  The challenge ends in Glasgow next Sunday  when Elaine and Susan line up for the Great Scottish Run Half Marathon.  Susan, 61, thought that Sunday&rsquos East Lothian run, which stretches from Musselburgh to Cockenzie and back, would be memorable.  She said: &ldquoIt will be the only one on Jenner&rsquos turf.  &ldquoI think that will be a wee bit special.  Already the family have completed three events, with Elaine, 33, running the Baker Hughes 10k in Aberdeen in May. Then Elaine lined up alongside Clare, 32, Kara, 29, Duncan, 28, and Susan for the Run the Blades event at Whitelee Wind Farm, near Eaglesham, in July.  The youngest members of the squad did their bit at the parkrun in Portrush, Northern Ireland, with Susan joined by Laura, 37, eight-year-old Isla, 14-year-old Ciara and Elaine.  Susan said: &ldquoI think we have all found it emotional &ndash just when you are standing on the start line waiting and we have had the odd laugh on the way round when something has happened.  &ldquoIn Aberdeen we thought it was going to pour with rain and the forecast was dreadful. It rained a bit and then went off and we said it was Jenner sorting that out for us.  Now the runners are in the home straight and each of them has been overwhelmed by the generosity of members of the public.  Initially a fundraising target of &pound1,000 was set before that was increased to &pound3,000, but both figures have been smashed.  Susan added: &ldquoI think the challenge itself was original and caught people&rsquos imagination but the total is not because of us.  &ldquoIt is a reflection of what Jenner was to so many people.  For more about the challenge or to make a donation, go to justgiving/fundraising/2018teamjenny

title: farewell-to-fizz-as-preston-lodge-high-school-ditches-drinks
story: The new initiative will begin from October 1 and follows a successful trial month earlier this year, &lsquoFizz-Free February&rsquo, when pupils were encouraged to only drink water in school.  Head Girl Anna Scott, 16, said that the move would have health benefits for pupils and increase concentration levels in classes.  &ldquoGet ready for a year of heightened focus and a stable, consistent level of energy throughout the day, along with improved learning ability, she said.  &ldquoWe are removing juice from our school and we need everyone to join in!  She also explained that there would be an added incentive for pupils to throw away their sugary drinks.  &ldquoThis time around we have decided to add a new reward system into the mix, along with an opportunity to support the house competition, she added.  &ldquoDuring the first month we will be rewarding house points in registration to those who have brought water to school with them and extra points for those who do so with reusable bottles.  &ldquoThe S6 events committee will be running a competition to see who can design the best poster for when the school goes fizz-free on October 1.  &ldquoThere will be a prize for the winner and their creation will be posted around the school to advertise the event.  Posters should be handed in to Mrs Nicoll by next Thursday  and must feature the phrase &lsquoJoin the Cleanse&rsquo.  They can be either emailed  or presented in a hard copy, and must also convey a positive attitude towards the goal of a water-only school.

title: dancing-teacher-jackie-is-the-new-strictly-champion
story: Strictly Leuchie raised thousands of pounds for Leuchie House, near North Berwick, when more than 350 people packed Haddington&rsquos Corn Exchange on September 8 to watch a fantastic dance show.  Eight couples were paired up at the end of June and spent 10 weeks learning and perfecting their dance moves.  Jackie Gentil, who is principal teacher at Macmerry Primary School, was crowned the winner alongside her dance partner Jane Libberton.  Mairi O&rsquoKeefe, Leuchie House CEO, said: &ldquoWe are thrilled that Strictly Leuchie has raised so much for our charity again this year.  &ldquoIt was a wonderful night and the dancers were incredible. To go from never having danced in public before to performing so well in front of a huge audience after only 10 weeks takes loads of hard work and commitment.  Joining Jackie on the dancefloor were Ali Wood , Alex Cunningham , Zoe Keddie-Dixon , Becky Everett , Callum Mark , Carol Fish , Joyce Lukkes-Presley  and Nicola Collin , along with seven professional dancers.  Each pair had a dferent dance style &ndash such as the jive, pasodoble, samba, cha cha cha, Bollywood and Irish dance &ndash to learn. After each couple had performed their routine, the audience voted for their three favourites.  Alex Cunningham and his partner Leigh Morrison, who performed a fast-paced Bollywood routine, which brought a touch of India to the Corn Exchange and Ali Wood, along with his partner Heather Antonelli, who did a salsa show dance to the soundtrack from The Greatest Showman, were announced as finalists alongside Jackie and Jane.  The audience then voted for a second time and chose Jackie and Jane and their high-kicking Irish dance as their winner.  Jackie, 46, who lives in Haddington with her husband and three sons, said she entered the competition after having a childhood desire to be in Pan&rsquos People!  Her dance partner Jane is a mum-of-four from Dunbar. As well as working as a post lady for Royal Mail, she teaches Irish dancing at the Aine Hay Academy of Irish Dance. She devised and choreographed the winning dance routine to the song The Irish Rover.  This is the 11th year a Strictly-themed competition has been organised for charity by Bett Morrison, from Gford.  Tibor Poc and Hilary Mouat, the Scottish amateur ballroom and Latin American champions, performed two Latin American demonstration dances, with the Aine Hay Irish Academy and Dunbar School of Dance also entertaining.  Bett said: &ldquoWhat a wonderful evening of dance and entertainment &ndash such a iety of styles of dance.  &ldquoWell done to everyone who took part and a special congratulations to the three couples who danced in the final &ndash they were all amazing.  Former Scottish international rugby player Andy Irvine presented the winning couple with the Niall Fairgrieve Memorial Trophy, presented annually to the competition winners in memory of a much-missed local rugby player.  Mrs O&rsquoKeefe added: &ldquoWe are very grateful to them, to all their professional partners, the amazing Bett Morrison, to our special guest Andy Irvine, to all the volunteers who helped on the night, and all the many other people who were involved in making it such a huge success.

title: rebecca-is-my-driving-force-says-mum-of-inspirational-teen-after-taking-on-great-north-run
story: Pam Dalgleish was among thousands taking part in the Great North Run in Newcastle and Tyneside.  Pam, of Kingston, was raising funds for the Teenage Cancer Trust, which provided support to daughter Rebecca, who passed away in December 2015.  The 18-year-old had been diagnosed with a malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour  and inspired people from across the county and beyond with her positive attitude.  Among Rebecca&rsquos achievements was raising more than &pound70,000 for Children&rsquos Hospices Across Scotland .  Pam completed the Great North Run last year and was again on the starting line on September 9.  She told the Courier each time she took part in an event it was emotional. She said: &ldquoRebecca is the driving force behind everything I do.  &ldquoI feel a great strength she has given me to carry on just by the way she was. I feel I have gained her strength and positivity to do this stuff.  About seven young people aged between 13 and 24 are diagnosed with a form of cancer every day in the UK.  Pam, 51, said: &ldquoI was just wanting to support the good causes that supported Rebecca when she was ill.  Pam completed the course in just over three hours and six minutes, raising more than &pound400 for the charity, and has not ruled out further fundraising challenges.  Rebecca&rsquos &lsquobucket list&rsquo included a bungee jump and a skye, something her mum fully intends to do in her daughter&rsquos memory.  Meanwhile, she is planning to swap her running shoes for her walking boots next year with another fundraiser in aid of CHAS.  Pam will be heading to Morocco for a trek in the Sahara in November next year.  More than 200 people attended former North Berwick High School pupil Rebecca&rsquos funeral three years ago.  Pam added: &ldquoIt will be three years at the end of this year, which is frightening.  &ldquoIn some ways it seems to have gone by in a flash and in other ways it does not.  To support Pam, go to just giving/fundraising/pam-dalgleish3

title: sad-passing-of-leading-conservation-volunteer-margaret-wight-89
story: A diminutive figure with a great sense of humour, Margaret won the East Lothian Volunteer of the Year award in 2012 for her work in particular with SOS Puffin, run by the Scottish Seabird Centre, and Aberlady Bay Local Nature Reserve.  Between 2007 and 2016, Margaret went out on almost 100 work parties with SOS Puffin to the islands of Craigleith and Fidra, to clear vegetation from puffin burrows.  She was also a volunteer at Aberlady Bay and, elsewhere, was a path warden and bumblebee monitor.  Born in Aberlady in 1929, Margaret grew up in ious East Lothian villages and was the eldest of seven children.  She left school at 14 and worked on a farm later she joined the WRNS, serving as a cook before she married and settled in North Berwick with husband William Wight and children Rodger and Fiona.  She worked for Crawford&rsquos the bakers for 20 years, including managing their North Berwick shop and for the last 16 years she lived in Macmerry.  On retirement, Margaret filled her le with voluntary activities &ndash as well as her conservation work, she was a fundraiser for the Children&rsquos Hospice Association Scotland , Poppyscotland and Children Living With Metabolic Diseases .  She joined charity expeditions to Everest Base Camp and Zimbabwe, and undertook two solo long-distance charity cycle rides in Scotland.  John Hunt, organiser of SOS Puffin, said: &ldquoMargaret was a wonderful supporter of SOS Puffin, coming out to the islands well into her 80s. At the end of a long work party, she would still be going strong while young ones were flagging.  &ldquoShe made many friends on these trips and left lots of happy memories.  John Harrison, warden of Aberlady Bay Local Nature Reserve, added: &ldquoMargaret was a truly inspirational person.  &ldquoMore often than not the first to get going on a task and the last to finish, Margaret would commonly work longer than volunteers a fraction of her age.  &ldquoShe was a very well-liked and fun member of the volunteer group, who achieved a great deal for nature conservation over the ten years she volunteered with us.  Margaret passed away at the Edington Hospital, North Berwick, on September 8 she is survived by her children Rodger and Fiona, and her grandchildren Moyra and Andrew.

title: farewell-to-long-serving-choristers-at-st-marys-parish-church
story: The youngsters left Knox Academy this summer, with plans to head to university, college, work or to travel.  A spokesman for St Mary&rsquos Parish Church said: &ldquoKara Singh, Phoebe Hayman, Robin Bellamy, Emma Wylie and Ailsa Wrinn have all sung with us since they were about eight or nine years old right up until S6.  &ldquoTheir talent, support and dedication has been greatly appreciated and has been an inspiration to many of the younger choristers.  &ldquoWe wish them all well in their future studies and travels in le.  Each of the teenagers was presented with a copy of Handel&rsquos Messiah on Sunday, September 2.  Meanwhile, the church has also said goodbye to Cole Bendall, the director of choirs, who has stood down for health reasons.  The spokesman added: &ldquoCole was only with us a short time but what an amazing time, with everyone benefiting from his marvellous musical talent. We will miss him and wish him all the very best for the future.  Anyone who is interested in further information about the choristers and choir at St Mary&rsquos can email choristers@stmaryskirk  Meanwhile, a specially-composed piece of music rung out at the church as part of the Haddington 700 celebrations on August 25.  A peal of 5,700 changes, which was specially composed for a new bell-ringing method named Haddington 700 Surprise Major, was rung by members of the Scottish Association of Change Ringers.  The peal band included two members from the St Mary&rsquos band of ringers.  Taking three hours and 21 minutes to complete, the peal provided a backdrop of celebratory sound to the events of the day.

title: boost-for-bid-to-create-community-co-working-space-on-dunbar-high-street
story: Sustaining Dunbar revealed proposals in May to buy the former housing office on Dunbar High Street from East Lothian Council.  It hopes to transform the building, which has lain empty for six years, into a workspace offering &ldquoinspiration and support to freelancers, commuters, remote workers, artists, businesses, social enterprises and community groups in and around the town.  The plan is a step closer after being awarded &pound8,640 from the Scottish Land Fund.  Sustaining Dunbar claims the project could add &pound800,000 a year to the local economy.  Osbert Lancaster, development officer, told the Courier: &ldquoThe building has been standing empty for some time.  &ldquoUntil we know the full condition of the building and cost of remedial work and refurbishment, we don&rsquot know  the project will be financially viable. This grant will let us engage an architect to assess the building and estimate the costs.  Sustaining Dunbar, formed in 2008, is a community development trust and charity. It aims to bring people together to create practical projects across the Dunbar and East Linton area that improve quality of le, support the local economy, and enhance the natural environment.  Mr Lancaster added: &ldquoIf we can make it happen, it should be a win-win all round.  &ldquoNot only will it be great for the people using the co-working centre, it will bring more people and more trade to High Street and boost the local economy.  &ldquoA study we commissioned suggests it will add between &pound600,000 and &pound800,000 to the area each year. And profits from the operation will be invested in practical support for local community groups and social enterprises.  Jo McNamara, chairwoman of Sustaining Dunbar, felt the funding boost was &ldquoa signicant step towards our vision of developing something really special in Dunbar.  She added: &ldquoWhile creating more workspace is essential for the area, what&rsquos truly exciting is the way co-working spaces like this can bring people together &ndash to share ideas, to collaborate and to build a stronger community.  For more information, go to coworkingdunbar

title: community-rallies-round-to-send-gymnast-hamish-colgan-to-portugal
story: Hamish Colgan, 19, is a gymnast and has been selected to represent the UK in the upcoming TeamGym European Championships, held in Lisbon, Portugal, next month.  Currently the TeamGym squad are not funded by GB Gymnastics and, as a result, athletes need to pay their own way regarding training, travelling, food and kit.  But in just 96 hours and after just one Facebook post, the &pound1,500 target was smashed &ndash but that came as no great shock to dad Hamish Snr.  &ldquoI wasn&rsquot surprised, no, he told the Courier.  &ldquoI know what people round here are like with charity, particularly in Tranent &ndash they&rsquore incredible.  &ldquoMaybe because it&rsquos something positive for a change and people like happy stories. It&rsquos all for a good cause anyway.  The appeal was initially posted on crowdfunding site JustGiving on August 31 by September 3, the amount of money raised stood at &pound1,580.  A fundraiser was arranged for next Saturday  in Macmerry Miners Welfare Club and Hamish said it would still go ahead.  Starting at 7pm, the evening includes a disco, a raffle and a buffet, with tickets &pound5.  Hamish revealed his son&rsquos massive commitment to the sport, packing it into a hectic schedule and giving it everything.  &ldquoHe&rsquos really busy just now, because he&rsquos a student and he&rsquos training to be a nurse, so he&rsquos got a packed schedule, he said.  &ldquoHe&rsquos got two jobs right now. He works in McDonald&rsquos and he works in a nursing home as part of his placement.  &ldquoHe&rsquos had to go to every training camp because  you don&rsquot go to every one you don&rsquot get picked, simple as that.  &ldquoThey&rsquore usually down in England the last half-dozen have all been in London. &ldquo  Due to the cost of travel, Hamish revealed there could be mixed emotions after a team selection.  &ldquoIt is bittersweet, he said. &ldquoI think there probably are some folk who just can&rsquot afford it.  &ldquoSometimes Hamish leaves himself skint just going to the training camps. But  you want to do it, you need to be able to pay.  &ldquoIt&rsquos a hard one. You could easily just chuck the towel in. But Hamish has gone this far, he couldn&rsquot throw it away now.  Another five athletes from East Lothian have been selected to go to the Championships, held in Oelas on October 17-20.  Adam Souter, Dylan Campbell , Sara Grfin , Carly McFadden  and Fraser McLeod  all train at Musselburgh club Saltire Team Gymnastics and were selected after a British competition in April.

story: Police and the fire service were also called out to the school at about 10.40am following reports that a female pupil had injured her leg. title: runners-raise-250000-in-scottish-half-marathon-and-10k
story: In excess of &pound250,000 was raised for more than&nbsp300 charities, led by the event&rsquos official charity Cancer Research UK, and its three established Scottish charities:&nbspChest Heart &amp Stroke Scotland, Alzheimer Scotland and Edinburgh Children&rsquos Hospital Charity.  Race participants were treated to glorious sunshine as the half-marathon runners&nbsppounded the streets from&nbspMeadowmill towards Longniddry, then near to the entrance of Gosford House before making their way back along the coast road to the finish line at&nbspMusselburgh Racecourse.  The 10k began at 9am, with Harry Burnard  crossing the finish line first in a time of 32:42.  He was followed in second by Michael Carroll  and in third by James Taylor .  Shona McIntosh  was the first lady home in a time of 36:56 with Freya Ross  and Zoe Pflug  coming second and third respectively.  In the 11am-start half-marathon - contested by 4,000 runners - Kevin Liddle  won with a time of 1:12:17.  He was chased home by Paul Featherstone  in second and Jason Kelly  in third.  After his win, Kevin said: "Today was great, the weather was better than anticipated. There were four of us together at the five mile mark and then I dropped back slightly up to the half way point. But I stuck to the pace and eventually caught them up again. I only really shook Paul [Featherstone] with one mile to go, so I'm delighted to take the win today."  Only two seconds split first and second in the women's field, with Kiera Gore  pipping Chloe Cox  to first place.  Claire Thomson  came third.

title: plaque-installed-to-mark-home-of-champion-golfer
story: Andrew and Audrey Inglis recently installed a plaque in memory of Willie Park senior  at their house on Ravensheugh Road &ndash near Musselburgh Links, one of the oldest golf courses in the world, where the famous Wallyford golfer spent his last days.  They found about the historical link from Ian Wood, former sub-postmaster at Levenhall, after he spotted information online about the four-time Open winner.  Mr Wood said: &ldquoIt made mention that he died at Levenhall.  &ldquoWhilst I knew a little bit about golf history and its strong links with Musselburgh during my 15 years, up until 2014, as sub-postmaster there, this was the first mention I&rsquod seen of the Willie Park connection to Levenhall as opposed to Musselburgh and the Old Course.  &ldquoI use the Scotland&rsquos People website run by the National Records of Scotland in my local and family history research so quite quickly found Willie&rsquos death registration in 1903 together with the Park family entry on the 1901 Census: both at Laurel Bank, Levenhall.  &ldquoI knew the house owners as former customers so when I next saw them I mentioned what I&rsquod discovered and expected them to know about it, particularly as Andrew, like me, is a keen golfer. However, this was news to him and his we Audrey so I passed them copies of what I&rsquod found.  Mr Inglis made contact with Historic Scotland which supported his request to have the plaque installed on the front of their house.  And Mr Inglis, who has lived in the house 34 years, said: &ldquoWe are quite proud to tell people about it. It is good to support Musselburgh&rsquos heritage and do everything you can to attract people to the town.  &ldquoI have been up to the loft to see  there are any of Willie Park senior&rsquos putters but there are none!  In a twist of fate, Mr Wood&rsquos daughter and son-in-law live on Park Drive, Wallyford, which was named after Willie Park senior, a four-time winner of The Open.  Mr Wood said: &ldquoI think the plaque is a fitting tribute to Willie Park senior.  He suggested that it would be good to see some kind of golfing trail, with accompanying leaflet, produced for the Honest Toun.  A successful golf exhibition, curated by the great-grandson of Willie Park senior, Mungo Park, was held at Musselburgh Museum in the summer. He was in the town again last week to give a talk on Musselburgh&rsquos importance in the history of the sport.  He said: &ldquoMusselburgh Museum&rsquos exhibition has just restored some of the town&rsquos proper reputation in golf history.  &ldquoI am grateful to the owners of Laurel Bank and to Historic Scotland for giving my great-grandfather a singular place in that history. There are many others in the town whose story is as rich, and I hope that Musselburgh&rsquos position as the 19th century&rsquos &lsquohome of golf&rsquo will come to be more widely understood.

title: sisters-set-to-raise-four-figure-sum
story: Musselburgh resident Veronica Noone, 57, took part in the September 9 event along with her sister Trisha Francis, 56, from Manchester, in aid of the charity Crohn&rsquos &amp Colitis UK after family members were diagnosed with the conditions.  They joined about 43,000 runners for the 13.1-mile half marathon which stretched from Newcastle-upon-Tyne to South Shields.  The siblings, who are originally from Tyneside, crossed the finishing line in two hours 30 minutes.  Sir Mo Farah sealed a record-breaking fth victory by winning the elite men&rsquos race in 59 minutes and 26 seconds.  Among the celebrities taking part were singer Olly Murs, news presenter Sophie Raworth and model Nell McAndrew.  Veronica, who has lived in Musselburgh for 25 years, and also serves as vice-chairwoman of Fisherrow Harbour and Seafront Association, said: &ldquoWe got on great and have so far raised &pound1,100 but there is still more coming in.  Veronica has also raised &pound270 by offering work colleagues at Scottish Enterprise the chance to repaint parts of a le-size cow model from Cow Parade Edinburgh in exchange for donations.  Its paint had been washed off following the event in 2006, but the now repainted brightly coloured cow stays on a balcony at Scottish Enterprise&rsquos Edinburgh office.  A &pound150 contribution was given to Veronica&rsquos cause from the staff charity fund.  Crohn&rsquos disease and ulcerative colitis are the two main forms of inflammatory bowel disease, affecting more than 300,000 people in the UK.  To donate, go to justgiving/fundraising/veronica-noone1

title: folk-favourites-yard-of-ale-ready-for-two-good-causes
story: The trio will raise funds for the Hollies Day Centre for older people and Musselburgh born Tom Fairnie, a singer-songwriter, who is preparing to go the musical trip of a letime to the USA.  Yard of Ale was originally formed in 1972 when Ian Lawson, Alistair McDougald and Colin Mackenzie all found themselves in Musselburgh.  Alistair and Colin had married local girls and Ian had taken up a post in youth and community education. He also later married a Musselburgh girl.  All three had dabbled in folk music in the past and regularly went to the Golf Tavern in Millhill, Musselburgh, to hear local folk singers, the Amulree Trio, Chris Egan and his daughters, Lorraine and Karen.  Alistair explained: "We each would sing a few songs inidually in the trio&rsquos break. One week John Gillan, the owner of the pub, asked  we could try and fill a night when the Amulrees were unavailable.  "We had a practice, everything just clicked and Yard Of Ale was born. We played every Friday and Saturday at the Golf for three years and took our name from the yard glass which hung on the wall. We were encouraged by local comedian, Billy Nimmo , to try our hand in the club cabaret scene."  Yard Of Ale then had many successful years on the pub and club circuit, winning the TV Times 'Pub Entertainers of the Year' award. The band did well on ITV's 'New Faces' and appeared on many television and radio shows including STV&rsquos 'Thingummyjig' and BBC Radio Scotland&rsquos 'Scottish Radio Orchestra Roadshow.' During this time they also supported, amongst others, Matt McGinn, Hamish Imlach and Billy Connolly, and enjoyed an extended run in the Edinburgh Festival with the legendary Tim Hardin.  They then went their separate ways with Alistair involved in solo cabaret work, Colin playing with the North Sea Gas folk group and Iain, the original guitarist, leading a rock band.  In 1992 the group reformed for a charity show at the Brunton Theatre with good friends The Mimics, a successful Musselburgh comedy showband who had also broken up previously, to mark the passing of their mentor Billy Nimmo. The event was so successful that the band decided to give it another go.  Since then its popularity has continued to grow and it has been in great demand for concerts, folk festivals, corporate s, pub, hotel and club gigs all over Scotland and when on tour in Denmark and in Ireland.  Peter Gillan, nephew of the Golf&rsquos John Gillan, then joined the band when Ian retired in 1998. Having spent many years playing solo as a singer and guitarist on the folk and country scenes, his experience added yet another dimension to the band.  Walter Mowat joined Yard Of Ale in 2015 when Colin retired. Over the years he has played in a number of folk and bluegrass bands and also plays violin in the Really Terrible Orchestra.  Ian and Colin still occasionally feature with the band as deputies or for larger concerts.  Alistair and Ian each have two sons who were brought up and educated in Musselburgh.  Alistair&rsquos sons were both taught at the Burgh School by Susan Macintosh, Peter&rsquos we.  Peter started his working le at Brunton&rsquos Wiremill and still works for Brunton Aero products as it is now. He has also become a leading light in the Musselburgh Athletic FC&rsquos 1934 Club.  Alistair was a director for 20 years of the now defunct Musselburgh Fair Day Association which ran the annual trotting at Musselburgh racecourse. He also ran a youth club for a number of years in Northesk Church and was chairman of the Musselburgh Domino League for a few years.  In August,Yard of Ale played a fundraiser for Musselburgh Athletic Football Club to help them achieve their transition to senior football.  The fundraising concert for the Hollies Day Centre has been organised by Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council. The sell-out event will take place on Friday at Loretto Church Hall.  The 'Get Tom To Austin Fundraising Concert' is planned for Saturday, November 3, at the Fisherrow Centre in South Street, Musselburgh. Mr Fairnie, 68, hoping to head to Texas next spring after being offered the chance to record an album of his own songs with the Grammy award winning producer Merel Bregante. formerly of the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band.

title: walkers-take-big-fit-walk-in-their-stride
story: The sun shone on the recent event which was supervised by 17 volunteer leaders. A Nordic walking session with specially designed walking poles was also enjoyed on the grassed area behind the Musselburgh East Community Learning Centre where the free event was based.  It was organised by two health groups: Ageing Well, a partnership between NHS Lothian and East Lothian Council, which promotes healthy lestyles for people over 50 in East Lothian and CHANGES Community Health Project, a charity which supports people in the county to find ways towards healthier and less stressful living.  Heather Cameron, project worker at CHANGES, said: "The event had a real community feel to it, with refreshments provided by Tesco, so that everyone could get a well earned cup of tea or coffee after ing from routes round the lagoons."  Anyone who didn&rsquot manage to go along on the day but would like to find out more about walking groups in East Lothian can contact either Heather on 0131 653 1080 or e-mail healthyliving@changeschp.org.uk or Parvine at Ageing Well on 01620 827 240 or email pjazayeri@eastlothian.gov.uk

title: fundraiser-rhona-taylor-reaches-finish-line-for-alzheimers-research-uk
story: Rhona Taylor joined hundreds of people across the country in signing up for Alzheimer&rsquos Research UK&rsquos Running Down Dementia.  The 21-year-old ran 100 kilometres to do her bit for the charity, which is close to her heart after her gran, Margaret Taylor, had dementia for about seven years.  Rhona said: &ldquoI think as well as getting the donations throughout, it really did spur me on knowing I was doing something in memory of my gran.  &ldquoSo many other people were doing the same challenge and being part of something bigger really helped.  &ldquoThere were a lot of days where I did not want to go out for a run, especially in the heatwave.  &ldquoIt was quite hard some days to keep going.  According to Alzheimer&rsquos Research UK, more than 1,700 people across the county have been diagnosed with dementia, with that figure expected to double within the next 20 years.  University student Rhona previously told the Courier she was not a keen athlete but found she had come on leaps and bounds during the challenge, which she finished at the end of August.  She said: &ldquoI really improved.  &ldquoI think for the first month, the improvement was so slow and I was pretty worried but one of my last runs was an eight-kilometre run.  &ldquoI could only run about a tenth of that in the beginning.  &ldquoOnce I got over that hump, it was crazy &ndash I was adding a kilometre every week to my personal best.  &ldquoFor me, time did not really matter.  &ldquoIt kind of came naturally and when I did shorter runs I was noticing I was getting a lot quicker but for me it was really about getting the distances since it seemed so unreachable for me in the beginning.  Rhona got involved with Dementia Friendly Haddington when she was still at Knox Academy.  She co-organised an event with fellow Knox pupil Kate Farmer at Haddington Day Centre, which saw an entire music class provide entertainment.  Since then, she has done her bit for dementia and Alzheimer-related charities, raising &pound546 through the challenge, and has not ruled out lacing up her running shoes again in the future after finding it not only improved her fitness but her mental health too.  Speaking on Friday morning, the fourth year studying film at Edinburgh Napier University added: &ldquoGenuinely, the reason I missed your call was I was about to go for a run.  &ldquoThat would be my first since I finished the challenge.  "I took a week off, I think I earned a week off but I am going to try to keep it up.  &ldquoI expected to get fitter but did not really expect how much of an impact it would have on my mood.  &ldquoJust genuinely you go for a run and there is no way you are going to feel bad afterwards.  To support Rhona, go to run ningdowndementia2018.everydayhero/uk/rhona

title: public-get-their-say-on-proposed-community-shelter-in-north-berwick
story: That comes after North Berwick Youth Project ditched plans to revamp the shelter at the Gladsclune area of the town following complaints from local residents.  Douglas Paul, chairman of Glasclune Residents Association, told the Courier earlier this summer that the proposals to redevelop the run-down shelter and turn it into a youth shelter were "second-rate."  He added: "We feel that it is the wrong site for this.  &ldquoWe are open to the accusation that it&rsquos because it is at the back of our house and that&rsquos partly fair &ndash ideally we&rsquod like to see the shelter pulled down."  Mr Paul, alongside half a dozen other local residents, attended a meeting of North Berwick Community Council  last week.  Lauren Cowie, manager from North Berwick Youth Project, also attended, and revealed their initial plans for Glasclune have now been shelved.  "We do not want to fight against people for this," she told the NBCC meeting in the Hope Rooms.  And she added: "We have listened to the feedback from local residents and we feel like we should look at alternative sites."  Previously Mr Paul and his we Kathryn told the Courier they would be "delighted" to help the youth project with fundraising.  And the re-iterated that stance at last week's meeting.  Mrs Paul said: "We have offered to fundraise with you and help manage the project and we'd be delighted to do that."  Ms Cowie thanked them for their offer.  However, Mrs Paul also said the run-down shelter remained a problem.  "It is 20 feet from our bedroom window and recently there's been homeless people sleeping in it.  "It still needs sorted out."  Mr and Mrs Paul have previously said they'd like the shelter knocked down.  The public consultation into a future site for the community shelter will take place in the Hope Rooms next Wednesday from 7pm.  All are welcome to attend.

title: uk-and-ecuador-seeking-end-to-assange-stand-off
story: President Lenin Moreno told The Associated Press that Mr Assange&rsquos lawyers are aware of the negotiations. He declined to provide more details because of the sensitivity of the case.  Mr Assange has been holed up in the embassy for more than six years.  The famous whistleblower and computer engineer faces an arrest warrant in the UK and fears he could be extradited to the US, where high-level officials have spoken about prosecuting him for stealing classied information.  Mr Moreno says his country will seek to protect Mr Assange&rsquos rights.  &ldquoBeing five or six years in an embassy already violates his human rights, he said, on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly. &ldquoBut his presence in the embassy is also a problem.  Ecuador&rsquos previous left-leaning administration gave Mr Assange asylum in 2012, saying it feared his le was in danger for publishing thousands of diplomatic cables that put US officials in a dficult position.  But Mr Assange&rsquos relationship with the Ecuadorian government has soured since the centrist Mr Moreno became president.  Over the past two years Mr Assange&rsquos access to the internet was suspended on several occasions, as he continued to publish material from the hacked accounts of politicians from dferent countries and made controversial statements on his social media accounts.  &ldquoI understand that currently he has no access  to stop him from doing that again, Mr Moreno said. &ldquoBut  Mr Assange promises to stop emitting opinions on the politics of friendly nations like Spain or the United States then we have no problem with him going online.  Ecuador&rsquos government has said Mr Assange&rsquos activities in the embassy, including the publishing of thousands of Hillary Clinton&rsquos emails prior to the 2016 election in the US, have compromised its relations with other countries.  &ldquoI don&rsquot agree with what he does, Mr Moreno said. &ldquoTo see someone violating people&rsquos right to communicate privately makes me feel uncomfortable.  Mr Assange has long argued that he is simply monitoring the actions of some of the world&rsquos most powerful politicians and exercising his right to free speech.

title: charles-to-present-iraq-campaign-medals-to-troops
story: The Black Watch, 3rd Battalion, The Royal Regiment of Scotland , have completed a&nbspsix-month operational tour of Iraq, based&nbspat Al-Asad Air Base in western Al-Anbar province.  Their two&nbspkey responsibilities were to provide the main security force for the near 4,000-strong coalition camp and to provide training and mentoring for Iraqi security forces, preparing them to lead security operations against Islamic State.  The training company taught their Iraqi partners in a range of areas, from security procedures, basic infantry tactics, le-saving first aid and communications to advanced weapon skills and basic improvised explosive device awareness.  Charles, who is Royal Colonel of 3 SCOTS, will present campaign medals and attend a reception at their base at Fort George near Inverness on Friday.  During their tour, 3 SCOTS worked alongside other nations, gaining experience manning security positions and honing their skills as a quick reaction force.  The soldiers also used their tour to raise money for the Army Benevolent Fund, hosted a successful Highland Games and took part in ious runs and activities hosted by other nations.

title: kavanaugh-hearing-what-we-learned-from-testimonies-of-judge-and-accuser
story: Both Mr Kavanaugh and Christine Blasey Ford, the woman accusing him of sexual assault when they were high school students, appeared before senators on Thursday. Mr Kavanaugh denied the accusation.  Here are some of the key takeaways from the extraordinary hearing:  What did Ms Ford say?  Ms Ford gave a soft-spoken and steady account about what she said happened three decades ago in a bedroom at a small gathering of friends. She said she came forward not for political reasons, but because it was her &ldquocivic duty.  She described in detail how an inebriated Mr Kavanaugh and another teenager, Mark Judge, locked her in a room at a house party as Mr Kavanaugh was grinding and groping her.  She said he put his hand over her mouth to muffle her screams, and testied: &ldquoI believed he was going to rape me.  The 51-year-old mother of two said the incident was seared into her mind through trauma, while admitting there were some gaps in her memory around the attack.  Ms Ford, a Calornia psychology professor making her first public remarks about the incident, choked up occasionally as she described the alleged attack.  Democratic senators questioned her directly, but the 11 Republican members on the committee instead chose to have a female sex crimes prosecutor from Arizona question her.  Asked how certain she was that Mr Kavanaugh was her attacker, she declared: &ldquo100%.  What did Mr Kavanaugh say?  Mr Kavanaugh ditched his prepared remarks and instead issued a blistering statement declaring the confirmation process &ldquoa national disgrace.  He strongly denied Ms Ford&rsquos allegation, but said he believed she had been the victim of a sexual assault. The father of two daughters said one of his girls said they should &ldquopray for the woman accusing him.  &ldquoThat&rsquos a lot of wisdom from a 10-year-old, he said, choking up.  Mr Kavanaugh&rsquos scorched-earth strategy gave president Donald Trump what he wanted: a nominee willing to fight back aggressively and yield no ground to Democrats.  Echoing Ms Ford, he said he was &ldquo100% certain he did not commit the assault.  At times, Mr Kavanaugh&rsquos frustrations boiled over. When Democratic Senator Amy Klobuchar asked  he had ever drunk so much he blacked out, he snapped: &ldquoHave you?.  He later apologised.  Moments after the hearing finished, Mr Trump tweeted that Mr Kavanaugh &ldquoshowed America exactly why I nominated him.  What happened to the prosecutor?  Republicans appointed prosecutor Rachel Mitchell to question Ms Ford, and she led off the questioning of Mr Kavanaugh. Then she quickly faded away.  After Ms Mitchell asked Mr Kavanaugh several detailed questions about Ms Ford&rsquos allegations, the GOP senators took matters into their own hands.  Senator Lindsey Graham led the way with a scorching denunciation of Democrats for raising the allegations against Mr Kavanaugh in the final days of the confirmation process.  From there, each GOP senator handled his own questions, while Ms Mitchell sat silently nearby.  Hours earlier, Ms Mitchell opened her questioning of Ms Ford by expressing sympathy for the professor, who said she was &ldquoterried to testy.  &ldquoI just wanted to let you know, I&rsquom very sorry. That&rsquos not right, Ms Mitchell said.  What happens next?  Republicans quickly expressed their determination to move forward. After huddling in the Capitol, senators said the Judiciary Committee would hold a Friday morning vote on whether to recommend Mr Kavanaugh for confirmation.  Senator Orrin Hatch of Utah, a long-time committee member, said he thinks Mr Kavanaugh will get confirmed by a party-line vote.  Republicans&rsquo margin for error in the full Senate is slim. If all Democrats oppose the nomination, just two GOP senators would sink Mr Kavanaugh&rsquos confirmation  they were to oppose him as well.  Multiple Republican politicians have not said which way they will vote, including two women with reputations as moderates who have been willing to buck their party &ndash Susan Collins of Maine and Lisa Murkowski of Alaska.  Mr Graham cautioned them against voting no.  &ldquoTo my Republican colleagues,  you vote no, you&rsquore legitimising the most despicable thing I have seen in my time in politics, he said.

title: independent-review-of-football-policing-strategy-ordered
story: Deputy Chief Constable Will Kerr said Police Scotland has an "enviable reputation" for how it polices large events, but that any "mature organisation" has to be able to challenge itself about how it could do better.  :&nbspCeltic fans describe scenes of &lsquototal chaos&rsquo in Parkhead &lsquocrushing&rsquo fears ahead of Old Firm  He told the Scottish Police Authority board meeting in Stirling that the appointment of the expert will be finalised in the next couple of weeks, and the review should be completed by Christmas.  He said: "Police Scotland has an enviable reputation for how it polices large public order, public safety events, recently the Ryder Cup, most recently the European Sports Championships or the Commonwealth Games.  "Whilst we're comfortable in how we police football matches, any mature learning organisation has to be comfortable enough to challenge itself and to reflect a bit, particularly where there is a public debate around how football matches are policed and to challenge ourselves about whether we could do it better, whether we could do it dferently, whether we could make some changes, and that's exactly what, having spoken to the chief over the last couple of years, we're very keen to do.  WATCH:&nbspTynecastle stewards &lsquocrush&rsquo Celtic fans entering stadium before match against Hearts  "I'm writing the terms of reference for an independent professional assurance review of how we police football matches generally across Scotland  "Essentially I want the review to be in two parts - one how we ally police football matches, how we gather intelligence, the flexibility of our deployment practices, how we manage risk at football matches.  "But equally importantly how the policing of those football matches feels, the tone and presentation of them, so we'd be very keen that the person we're going to commission speaks to a range of stakeholders involved in football matches, everything from SFA to SPFL right through to some supporters' clubs and football clubs themselves."  :&nbspEx-Celtic reserve player Graeme Morrison dies aged just 41 after losing cancer battle  News of the review emerged just over three weeks after fans were injured in a crush at an Old Firm game.    Five people needed medical treatment following the incident at Parkhead as fans tried to get into the stadium before the first Celtic v Rangers game of the season on September 2.    Police Scotland stressed the review is not specically about that incident or any other, but about the policing of matches in a wider sense.

title: Iain Macwhirter  Salmond   s determination to clear his name could tear the SNP apart
story: The former First Minister is the most formidable fighter in politics and will not to go quietly into that good political night. His determination to clear his name of allegations of sexual impropriety has the potential to tear the Scottish Government and the SNP apart. The two most important politicians in the modern history of Scottish nationalism have been pitted against each other at the very moment the party needs to unite over the future of independence.  We've had the extraordinary spectacle of the former First Minister, and SNP leader, conducting a war of legal words over social media with the current First Minister, and SNP leader.
